questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with exertional dyspnea, and chest pain. Echo was done and showed severe aortic stenosis, He has hypertension, chronic kidney disease (stage G4), hyperlipidemia, severe COPD, and atrial fibrillation. What is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transcatheter aortic valve implantation is recommended in preference to surgical aortic valve replacement for symptomatic patients with severe aortic stenosis who are older than 80 years or younger patients with a life expectancy less than 10 years.
  • ➤ Transcatheter aortic valve implantation is recommended for symptomatic patients of any age with severe aortic stenosis and a high or prohibitive surgical risk if predicted post procedure survival is more than 12 months with an acceptable quality of life.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion and fatigue. Physical examination reveals an early diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases with inspiration. ECG shows right axis deviation and right atrial enlargement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Presents with a diastolic murmur at the left sternal border but decreases with inspiration.
  • • Option A. Aortic regurgitation:
  • • Option B. Mitral stenosis: Presents with a diastolic murmur at the apex and does not increase with inspiration.
  • • Option B. Mitral stenosis:
  • • Option D. Pulmonary regurgitation: Presents with a diastolic murmur at the left sternal border but decreases with inspiration.
  • • Option D. Pulmonary regurgitation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical presentation of tricuspid stenosis, including the characteristic murmur and ECG findings.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with fatigue and near-syncope with exertion. He has a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur along the right upper sternal border that increases with squatting. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM): The murmur of HCM is typically heard best at the left lower sternal border and decreases with squatting.
  • • Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM):
  • • Option C. Restrictive membranous ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSDs typically present with a holosystolic murmur, not a systolic ejection murmur.
  • • Option C. Restrictive membranous ventricular septal defect (VSD):
  • • Option D. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm: This typically presents with a continuous murmur.
  • • Option D. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Systolic ejection murmur along the right upper sternal border that increases with squatting as a classic finding of a bicuspid aortic valve.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy and severe secondary mitral regurgitation (MR) is on maximally tolerated guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) and is now asymptomatic. What is the most appropriate additional management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging ( MRI): Unnecessary if the mechanism and severity of MR are already well-established.
  • • Option A. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging ( MRI):
  • • Option B. Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT): Indicated for patients with LVEF ≤35%, QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II-IV symptoms despite GDMT. Not applicable here.
  • • Option B. Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT):
  • • Option C. Surgical mitral valve repair: Considered if the patient remains symptomatic despite optimal GDMT or if there is progressive LV enlargement.
  • • Option C. Surgical mitral valve repair:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In asymptomatic patients with severe secondary MR due to LV dysfunction, optimal GDMT is the first-line therapy and usually sufficient.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman with no medical problems presents with a diminished S1, an aortic ejection click, and a grade 2/6 early diastolic murmur at the left sternal border that is accentuated when leaning forward. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac catheterization: Invasive and not the initial step for a new murmur.
  • • Option A. Cardiac catheterization:
  • • Option B. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): More expensive and not routinely used as the first-line investigation.
  • • Option B. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
  • • Option C. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE): More invasive than TTE and reserved for cases where TTE is inconclusive or there is a high suspicion of endocarditis or other valvular pathology.
  • • Option C. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is the initial diagnostic test of choice for evaluating a new cardiac murmur.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man presents with a 3 hour history of chest pain. His BP is 80/50 mmHg, HR is 120/min and has elevated JVP and clear lungs. ECG is shown. What is the most appropriate treatment ?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Intra-aortic balloon pump placement: Indicated in cardiogenic shock with LV dysfunction, but not the first-line treatment for RV infarction.
  • • Option A. Intra-aortic balloon pump placement:
  • • Option B. Intravenous dobutamine: Inotrope may be considered if fluids are ineffective, but not the initial management.
  • • Option B. Intravenous dobutamine:
  • • Option D. Oral metoprolol: Beta-blockers can worsen hypotension and should be avoided in RV infarction.
  • • Option D. Oral metoprolol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patient with an inferior myocardial infarction with right ventricular involvement and hypotension should receive intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation and severe primary mitral regurgitation (MR) due to mitral valve prolapse has an LVEF of 55% and LV end-systolic dimension of 60 mm. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): Unnecessary if the mechanism and severity of MR are already established by TTE.
  • • Option A. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
  • • Option C. Transcatheter mitral valve repair (TMVR): Considered in patients with favourable anatomy and high risk for surgical repair.
  • • Option C. Transcatheter mitral valve repair (TMVR):
  • • Option D. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE): May be helpful if TTE is inconclusive, but not necessary in this case.
  • • Option D. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgery for chronic primary severe mitral regurgitation is indicated in the presence of symptoms, left ventricular dilation, or reduced ejection fraction.
  • ➤ Surgical mitral valve repair is first-line therapy for patients with primary severe mitral regurgitation meeting indications for intervention.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a mechanical mitral valve prosthesis is planning pregnancy. She is currently on warfarin 4mg with a stable INR of 3.0. What is the most appropriate anticoagulation strategy during the first trimester?

options.label: C
options.text: Stop warfarin and start subcutaneous dose-adjusted unfractionated heparin (UFH)

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Stop warfarin and start Bivalirudin: Not recommended for long-term anticoagulation in pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Stop warfarin and start Bivalirudin:
  • • Option B. Stop warfarin and start Dabigatran : Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are not recommended in pregnancy due to limited safety data.
  • • Option B. Stop warfarin and start Dabigatran
  • • Option C. Stop warfarin and start subcutaneous dose-adjusted unfractionated heparin UFH: Can be considered if warfarin dose is >5 mg/d or if the patient prefers to avoid warfarin during the first trimester.
  • • Option C. Stop warfarin and start subcutaneous dose-adjusted unfractionated heparin
  • • UFH:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant for pregnant women with mechanical heart valves if the dose is ≤5 mg/d.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of aortic valve replacement and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis presents with progressive fatigue, fever, shortness of breath and bilateral basal crackles. ECG shows first degree AV block. Echocardiogram shows a vegetation on the aortic valve bioprosthesis with severe aortic regurgitation. After blood cultures and empiric antibiotics are initiated, what is the most appropriate management?
questions.correct_answer: B. Early surgical aortic valve replacement
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac catheterization: Can be done in selected patients at the time of surgery to determine the need of coronary artery bypass grafting.
  • • Option A. Cardiac catheterization:
  • • Option C. Placement of a temporary pacemaker: Not the most important step at this point.
  • • Option C. Placement of a temporary pacemaker:
  • • Option D. No change in therapy: Inadequate as surgery is required for definitive management of PVE with complications.
  • • Option D. No change in therapy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Early surgical valve replacement is indicated in patients with IE and heart failure, annular or aortic abscess, or destructive penetrating lesions.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with exertional dyspnea and elevated BNP. 2D Echo shows EF of 45% and low-flow, low-gradient severe aortic stenosis. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac catheterization: In this patient who likely has low cardiac output, direct measurement of the aortic valve gradient by cardiac catheterization (Option A) would result in low gradients that underestimate the severity of the AS, similar to gradient and velocity values on resting echocardiography. Dobutamine catheterization may be performed in lieu of dobutamine echocardiography in this case.
  • • Option A. Cardiac catheterization:
  • • Option C. & option D. Surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) or Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI): Proceeding to surgical or transcatheter aortic valve implantation is inappropriate at this time; the resting echo does not adequately differentiate between pseudosevere AS due to insufficient stroke volume and low-flow, low-gradient severe AS.
  • • Option C. & option D.
  • • Surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) or Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnose low-flow, low-gradient severe symptomatic aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, diabetes mellitus, and severe aortic stenosis undergoes coronary angiography, revealing diffuse coronary artery disease requiring CABG. Her ascending aorta measures 5.6 cm in diameter. What additional intervention is most appropriate?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aortic valve replacement (AVR): Does not address the TAA, which has a high risk of rupture.
  • • Option A. Aortic valve replacement (AVR):
  • • Option C. Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI): Contraindicated in patients with concomitant significant CAD and TAA.
  • • Option C. Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI):
  • • Option D. No intervention: This would leave the patient at risk for aortic dissection or rupture.
  • • Option D. No intervention:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with an ascending aorta or aortic root larger than 4.5 cm in diameter who require surgery for CAD or valve pathology, aortic repair should be performed at the time of cardiac surgery.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man had a mechanical mitral valve replacement 1 year ago. He is currently on warfarin and his INR is 3.4. He now presents with easy bruising and scattered ecchymoses. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Decreasing warfarin dosage: Would increase the risk of thromboembolic events.
  • • Option B. Decreasing warfarin dosage:
  • • Option C. Discontinue warfarin and start aspirin: Not sufficient for anticoagulation in patients with mechanical valves.
  • • Option C. Discontinue warfarin and start aspirin:
  • • Option D. Discontinue warfarin and start dabigatran : DOACs are not recommended for patients with mechanical valves (based on the data from Re-ALIGN trial).
  • • Option D. Discontinue warfarin and start dabigatran

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a prosthetic cardiac valve, the appropriate INR goal varies by type of valve and valve position, with a goal INR of 3.0 (range 2.5-3.5) for a mechanical valve in the mitral position. Dabigatran is associated with excess bleeding and thrombosis, and the safety of other direct oral anticoagulants has not been assessed.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with exertional dyspnea and syncope has echocardiographic findings of severe aortic stenosis (AS) and a bicuspid aortic valve. What is the most next step?

options.label: B
options.text: CT angiography of the thoracic aorta

questions.correct_answer: B. CT angiography of the thoracic aorta
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac catheterization: May be needed to evaluate coronaries if intermediate to high pre-test probability. If low pre-test probability, CTA of the coronaries can be along with CTA of the aorta.
  • • Option A. Cardiac catheterization:
  • • Option C. Exercise treadmill stress testing: C/I in symptomatic severe AS due to the risk of adverse events.
  • • Option C. Exercise treadmill stress testing:
  • • Option D. Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI): Not appropriate before assessing the aorta, as aortic pathology might influence the choice of intervention.
  • • Option D. Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with bicuspid aortic valve and suspected aortic stenosis, evaluate the thoracic aorta before proceeding with any intervention.

questions.text: A 63-year-old asymptomatic man has severe aortic regurgitation (AR) with normal left ventricular (LV) ejection fraction (EF) and elevated LV end-systolic dimension (45 mm). What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR): Not indicated yet due to lack of symptoms and only mild LV enlargement.
  • • Option B. Surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR):
  • • Option C. Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI): Not recommended for isolated severe AR in patients who are candidates for surgery.
  • • Option C. Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI):
  • • Option D. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE): May be helpful if TTE image quality is poor, but not necessary in this case.
  • • Option D. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In symptomatic patients with severe aortic regurgitation, aortic valve surgery is indicated regardless of left ventricular systolic function.
  • ➤ In asymptomatic patients with chronic severe aortic regurgitation and left ventricular systolic dysfunction (EF ≤55%), aortic valve surgery is indicated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for exertional dyspnea and a sensation of pounding in the neck that has progressed over the last year. Blood pressure is 150/60 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. The following murmur is heard over the left sternal edge. Identify the cause.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis: Is a systolic murmur.
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis:
  • • Option C. Mitral stenosis: Produces a low-frequency diastolic murmur heard best at the apex.
  • • Option C. Mitral stenosis:
  • • Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: The murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is also heard during systole, and the intensity may increase with inspiration.
  • • Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation:

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for exertional dyspnea. She was previously asymptomatic, but 4 months ago she began having shortness of breath during moderate activity. Blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg, pulse rate is 80/min, and respiration rate is 22/min. Auscultation is performed at the upper right sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option B. Mitral regurgitation: Produces a higher-pitched, holosystolic murmur that is loudest at the apex.
  • • Option B. Mitral regurgitation:
  • • Option C. Pulmonic stenosis: The murmur of pulmonic stenosis is heard best at the left upper sternal border and may increase in intensity with inspiration.
  • • Option C. Pulmonic stenosis:
  • • Option D. ventricular septal defect: A small ventricular septal defect without pulmonary hypertension presents with a loud and often palpable holosystolic murmur located at the left sternal border that may obliterate the S2. Progressive pulmonary hypertension results in shortening of the murmur.
  • • Option D. ventricular septal defect:

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for an 8-hour history of acute-onset, sharp, and persistent chest pain. Blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation is performed with the diaphragm at the left sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation is a high-pitched diastolic murmur heard best along the mid-left upper sternal border.
  • • Option A. Aortic regurgitation:
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis: The murmur of aortic stenosis is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur loudest at the upper right sternal edge.
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis:
  • • Option C. Patent ductus arteriosus: A continuous murmur of patent ductus arteriosus begins in systole and extends without interruption into diastole.
  • • Option C. Patent ductus arteriosus:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for an 18-month history of progressive fatigue and dyspnea. Blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg, pulse rate is 76/min, and respiration rate is normal. The apical impulse is slightly sustained but not displaced. Auscultation is performed at the cardiac apex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation produces a high-pitched diastolic murmur heard best along the mid left sternal border.
  • • Option A. Aortic regurgitation:
  • • Option B. Mitral regurgitation: Mitral regurgitation produces a high-pitched holosystolic murmur loudest at the cardiac apex.
  • • Option B. Mitral regurgitation:
  • • Option D. Pulmonic regurgitation: The murmur of pulmonic regurgitation is early diastolic, best heard over the left second and third interspaces and increases in intensity with inspiration.
  • • Option D. Pulmonic regurgitation:

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman is evaluated for a heart murmur. Blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation is performed with firm pressure on the diaphragm at the cardiac apex. Which of the following findings accounts for the auscultatory findings at the apex?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis: Aortic stenosis produces a harsh, systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is loudest at the right upper sternal edge.
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis:
  • • Option C. Mitral stenosis: The murmur of mitral stenosis is heard during diastole at the cardiac apex. A pericardial friction rub may consist of one to three components and may be heard in systole, diastole, or both systole and diastole.
  • • Option C. Mitral stenosis:
  • • Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: The holosystolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is heard loudest at the lower left sternal edge, and the intensity may increase with inspiration.
  • • Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation:

questions.text: Loud S1 in mitral stenosis (MS) is lost in all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. First-degree heart block: A classic cause of soft S1.
  • • Option A. First-degree heart block:
  • • Option B. Aortic Regurgitation (AR): Can cause volume overload of the LV and soft S1.
  • • Option B. Aortic Regurgitation (AR):
  • • Option C. Calcified valve: Calcification of the mitral valve leaflets leads to reduced mobility and a softer S1.
  • • Option C.
  • • Calcified valve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitral stenosis is typically associated with a loud S1, this characteristic finding can be lost or diminished in cases of calcified valves.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman came for a routine health check-up. She has no symptoms, and on examination, she has a grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex. 2D Echo demonstrates severe Mitral regurgitation with LVEF of 50%. The left ventricle is moderately dilated with an LV end-systolic dimension (LVESD) of 42 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Serial clinical and echocardiographic evaluations: While monitoring is important, it is not the most appropriate next step in this case of severe MR with LV dilatation. Delaying surgery can lead to irreversible LV damage and worsening of symptoms.
  • • Option A. Serial clinical and echocardiographic evaluations:
  • • Option C. Surgical mitral valve replacement: Replacement is considered if repair is not feasible or if the mitral valve is severely damaged. However, repair is the preferred option whenever possible.
  • • Option C. Surgical mitral valve replacement:
  • • Option D. Transcatheter mitral valve repair: This is a less invasive option but is currently recommended for patients who are high-risk surgical candidates. This patient is asymptomatic and otherwise healthy, making her a good candidate for surgical repair.
  • • Option D. Transcatheter mitral valve repair:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indications for surgical mitral valve repair in asymptomatic patients include severe primary MR and LV dilatation (ESD ≥ 40mm and/or EF ≤ 60%).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with recurrent chest pain and dyspnea. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Physical exam reveals elevated JVP, crackles, and a soft early systolic murmur with an S3 gallop. ECG is shown. Chest X-ray shows pulmonary congestion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis: While this can cause heart failure, it would present with a harsh systolic murmur radiating to the carotids, not a soft early systolic murmur.
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis:
  • • Option B. Cardiac tamponade: This can cause elevated JVP and distant heart sounds, but it would not typically present with a new murmur or ECG changes of MI.
  • • Option B. Cardiac tamponade:
  • • Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: This would cause a holosystolic murmur that increases with inspiration, not the early systolic murmur described in this case.
  • • Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute MR usually occurs in association with inferior MI and it is due to rupture of posteromedial papillary muscle.

questions.text: All of the following indicate severe mitral stenosis except?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Soft S1: In severe MS, the mitral valve leaflets become thickened and calcified, resulting in a softer first heart sound (S1).
  • • Option A. Soft S1:
  • • Option B. Increased duration of MDM: As the severity of mitral stenosis increases, the mid-diastolic murmur (MDM) becomes longer due to the prolonged flow of blood across the narrowed valve.
  • • Option B. Increased duration of MDM:
  • • Option D. Palpable P2: In severe MS, pulmonary hypertension often develops, leading to accentuated pulmonary component of the second heart sound (P2), which can be palpable.
  • • Option D. Palpable P2:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Short A2-OS gap is a marker of severe mitral stenosis.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of a soft first heart sound except?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Calcified valves: Calcification of the mitral valve leaflets can make them rigid and less mobile, leading to a softer S1.
  • • Option A. Calcified valves:
  • • Option B. Mitral regurgitation: In some cases of mitral regurgitation, the mitral valve may not close completely, resulting in a softer S1.
  • • Option B. Mitral regurgitation:
  • • Option C. Heart failure: Reduced left ventricular contractility in heart failure can lead to less forceful closure of the mitral valve and a softer S1.
  • • Option C. Heart failure:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperdynamic states are associated with loud S1.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with a history of connective tissue disease presents with acute shortness of breath and pulmonary edema. Examination reveals severe aortic regurgitation due to a right coronary cusp avulsion. She is in cardiogenic shock. What intervention is most likely to maintain end-organ perfusion until surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Esmolol continuous IV infusion titrated to a heart rate of 60–70 beats/min

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Esmolol (beta-blocker) continuous IV infusion titrated to a heart rate of 60–70 beats/min: Slowing the heart rate increases diastolic time, worsening regurgitation.
  • • Option A. Esmolol (beta-blocker) continuous IV infusion titrated to a heart rate of 60–70 beats/min:
  • • Option B. Intra-aortic balloon pump: Contraindicated in severe aortic regurgitation, as it inflates during diastole, further increasing regurgitation.
  • • Option B. Intra-aortic balloon pump:
  • • Option D. IV norepinephrine : IV norepinephrine and E. Vasopressin: These are vasopressors that increase afterload, which would worsen aortic regurgitation.
  • • Option D.
  • • IV norepinephrine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute severe aortic regurgitation with cardiogenic shock, IV nitroprusside can be used as a bridge to surgery by reducing afterload and improving forward flow.

questions.text: Mrs. Vinitha, a 24-year-old woman with severe mitral stenosis, presents with acute dyspnea and fatigue. On exam, her BP is 110/70 mm Hg and her HR is 50/min. She has bilateral crackles on auscultation. Which of the following interventions would NOT be beneficial?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. IV furosemide: Lowers left atrial pressure and it is beneficial in mitral stenosis.
  • • Option A. IV furosemide:
  • • Option B. Percutaneous balloon mitral valvotomy (PBMV): Lowers LA-LV pressure gradient by opening up the stenosed valve and hence it is beneficial in mitral stenosis.
  • • Option B. Percutaneous balloon mitral valvotomy (PBMV):
  • • Option D. All of the above: This is incorrect, as pacing can be associated with worsening of pulmonary congestion in mitral stenosis.
  • • Option D. All of the above:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sinus bradycardia is advantageous in the setting of mitral stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is false?

options.label: A
options.text: MVP is more common in connective tissue diseases such as Marfan syndrome.

options.label: B
options.text: MVP occurs more commonly in women than in men.

options.label: C
options.text: The anterior leaflet is usually more affected than the posterior leaflet.

options.label: D
options.text: The click and murmur of MVP will occur early with the initiation phase of Valsalva.

questions.correct_answer: C. The anterior leaflet is usually more affected than the posterior leaflet.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In most patients with MVP, the cause is unknown. MVP is a frequent finding in patients with heritable disorders of connective tissue, including Marfan syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Ehlers- Danlos syndrome. The posterior mitral leaflet is usually more affected than the anterior, and the mitral valve annulus is often dilated. MVP is more common in women and occurs most frequently between the ages of 15 and 30 years; the clinical course is most often benign. A frequent physical examination finding is the mid or late (nonejection) systolic click, followed by a highpitched, mid-late systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur and is heard best at the apex. Radiation of the murmur will depend on the involved leaflet. With posterior leaflet prolapse, the jet of mitral regurgitation (MR) is directed anteriorly and the murmur will radiate to the base of the heart. With anterior leaflet involvement, the jet of MR is directed posteriorly and the murmur will radiate to the axilla and back. The click and murmur occur earlier with standing, during the strain phase of the Valsalva maneuver, and with any intervention that decreases left ventricular (LV) volume (preload), exaggerating the propensity of mitral leaflet prolapse. Conversely, squatting and isometric exercises, which increase LV volume, diminish MVP; the click-murmur omplex is delayed, moves away from S1, and may even disappear.
  • • In most patients with MVP, the cause is unknown.
  • • MVP is a frequent finding in patients with heritable disorders of connective tissue, including Marfan syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Ehlers- Danlos syndrome.
  • • The posterior mitral leaflet is usually more affected than the anterior, and the mitral valve annulus is often dilated.
  • • MVP is more common in women and occurs most frequently between the ages of 15 and 30 years; the clinical course is most often benign.
  • • A frequent physical examination finding is the mid or late (nonejection) systolic click, followed by a highpitched, mid-late systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur and is heard best at the apex.
  • • Radiation of the murmur will depend on the involved leaflet. With posterior leaflet prolapse, the jet of mitral regurgitation (MR) is directed anteriorly and the murmur will radiate to the base of the heart. With anterior leaflet involvement, the jet of MR is directed posteriorly and the murmur will radiate to the axilla and back.
  • • The click and murmur occur earlier with standing, during the strain phase of the Valsalva maneuver, and with any intervention that decreases left ventricular (LV) volume (preload), exaggerating the propensity of mitral leaflet prolapse. Conversely, squatting and isometric exercises, which increase LV volume, diminish MVP; the click-murmur omplex is delayed, moves away from S1, and may even disappear.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MVP is more common in women and occurs most frequently between the ages of 15 and 30 years; the clinical course is most often benign.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presented with fatigue. Cardiac catheterization is done and it is demonstrated below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis : This would show a pressure gradient between the left ventricle and the aorta during systole.
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation : This would show a high-pressure V wave in the left atrial pressure tracing during systole, due to blood regurgitating back into the left atrium.
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation : This would show an elevated left ventricular diastolic pressure and a rapid decline in aortic pressure during diastole.
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ LA-LV gradient during diastole is characteristic of mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female presented with palpitations and generalized tiredness. Cardiac catheterization is done, and the results are shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mitral regurgitation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Mitral stenosis : In mitral stenosis, there would be a pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle during diastole, leading to an elevated LA pressure throughout diastole, not just during systole.
  • • Option A. Mitral stenosis
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis : This would show a pressure gradient between the left ventricle and the aorta during systole.
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation : This would show an elevated left ventricular diastolic pressure and a rapid decline in aortic pressure during diastole.
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Large ‘v’ wave in LA pressure tracing during ventricular systole is characteristic of mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with chest pain. Cardiac catheterization is done and it is demonstrated below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Mitral stenosis : This would show a pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle during diastole.
  • • Option A. Mitral stenosis
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation : This would show a high-pressure V wave in the left atrial pressure tracing during systole, due to blood regurgitating back into the left atrium.
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation : This would show an elevated left ventricular diastolic pressure and a rapid decline in aortic pressure during diastole.
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The pressure gradient between the LV and the aorta during systole is hallmark of LVOT obstruction (like aortic stenosis).

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented with palpitations and chest pain. Cardiac catheterization is done, and the results are shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Mitral stenosis: This would cause a pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle during diastole, leading to an elevated left atrial pressure.
  • • Option A. Mitral stenosis:
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis : This would show a pressure gradient between the left ventricle and the aorta during systole, causing the aortic pressure to rise more slowly and not reach as high a peak.
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation : This would show a prominent V wave in the left atrial pressure tracing during systole, due to blood regurgitating back into the left atrium.
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Low diastolic blood pressure in aorta and elevated LV diastolic pressure are hallmarks of aortic regurgitation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old asymptomatic man is found to have a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with left- atrial and ventricular enlargement on echocardiogram. The estimated right ventricular systolic pressure is 30 mmHg and RV is normal in size. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Cardiac MRI : While it can provide detailed information, echocardiography is sufficient to confirm the diagnosis and indication for closure.
  • • Option A. Cardiac MRI
  • • Option B. Indomethacin : Used to close PDA in premature infants, not effective in adults.
  • • Option B. Indomethacin
  • • Option D. Serial echocardiographic monitoring : Not recommended when closure is already indicated due to left heart enlargement.
  • • Option D. Serial echocardiographic monitoring

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ PDA closure is indicated in patients with left-sided cardiac chamber enlargement even in the absence of symptoms, as long as PA systolic pressure is < 50% of systemic.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with transient right-sided weakness. Evaluation reveals a small ischemic stroke and a patent foramen ovale (PFO) with right-to-left shunt. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Aspirin : Antiplatelet therapy alone is less effective than PFO closure in preventing recurrent stroke.
  • • Option A. Aspirin
  • • Option C. Warfarin : Anticoagulation may be considered in older patients or those with contraindications to PFO closure.
  • • Option C. Warfarin
  • • Option D. Observation : Not appropriate due to the high risk of recurrent stroke in this scenario.
  • • Option D. Observation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ PFO closure is recommended for younger patients (< 60y) with cryptogenic stroke and PFO to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is evaluated for exertional dyspnea. Physical exam reveals a continuous murmur beneath the left clavicle, fixed splitting of S2, and right axis deviation on ECG. Echocardiogram shows a 1.5-cm ostium secundum atrial septal defect (ASD) with moderate right heart enlargement. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Cardiopulmonary exercise testing : Not necessary as the cause of dyspnea (ASD) is already established.
  • • Option B. Cardiopulmonary exercise testing
  • • Option C. Coronary angiography : Not indicated in this patient with a congenital heart defect.
  • • Option C. Coronary angiography
  • • Option D. Echocardiographic surveillance : Not sufficient, as the ASD requires closure.
  • • Option D. Echocardiographic surveillance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Atrial septal defect closure is indicated for symptomatic patients or those with right heart enlargement to prevent long-term complications.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman with Eisenmenger syndrome due to PDA presents with heavy menstrual periods and fatigue. Prior to onset of symptoms her Hb was 18g/dL and now her Hb is 14.7 g/dL. Her serum ferritin levels were low. She is receiving bosentan for pulmonary hypertension. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Hysterectomy : Surgical interventions are better avoided in Eisenmenger’s syndrome owing to increased peri-operative risk. If menorrhagia is presumed to be the cause of anemia, can try endometrial ablation, intrauterine device placement, and, rarely, hysterectomy.
  • • Option A. Hysterectomy
  • • Option C. Phlebotomy : Indicated for symptomatic hyperviscosity (especially if Hb > 20g/dL and/or Hct > 65% in the absence of dehydration).
  • • Option C. Phlebotomy
  • • Option D. Supplemental oxygen : Not the primary treatment in this patient (if used, do not use SpO2 targets, rather target symptomatic relief in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome).
  • • Option D. Supplemental oxygen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Correction of iron deficiency is associated with increased exercise capacity and improved quality of life in patients with cyanotic congenital heart disease.
  • ➤ Adaptive erythrocytosis is well tolerated in patients with cyanotic congenital heart disease, and therapeutic phlebotomy is not indicated until Hb > 20 g/dL.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of repaired tetralogy of Fallot presents for routine follow up. On exam, he has a grade 1/6 early systolic murmur localized to the left second intercostal space and a grade 2/6 diastolic murmur best heard in the left second and third intercostal spaces, that increases with inspiration.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Aortic coarctation : Usually presents with upper extremity hypertension and a systolic murmur in the left infraclavicular area.
  • • Option A. Aortic coarctation
  • • Option B. Aortic regurgitation : Diastolic murmur at the left sternal border that does not increase with inspiration (it rather increases with expiration).
  • • Option B. Aortic regurgitation
  • • Option C. Mitral stenosis : Diastolic rumble at the apex, not associated with TOF repair.
  • • Option C. Mitral stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Severe PR causes a diastolic murmur heard at the left sternal border that increases in intensity with inspiration, a parasternal lift, and a soft systolic pulmonary outflow murmur.
  • ➤ PR is the most common postoperative sequela of TOF repair .

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea, a systolic murmur at the left second intercostal space, a diastolic flow rumble over the tricuspid valve, and fixed splitting of the second heart sound (S2). ECG is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic regurgitation

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Bicuspid aortic valve with AR : Would have a diastolic murmur at the left sternal border.
  • • Option B. Bicuspid aortic valve with AR
  • • Option C. Mitral stenosis : Would have a diastolic murmur at the apex.
  • • Option C. Mitral stenosis
  • • Option D. VSD : Typically presents with a holosystolic murmur.
  • • Option D. VSD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical and ECG findings suggestive of an ASD.
  • ➤ as amyloidosis, should be considered. Serum protein electrophoresis/urine protein electrophoresis and free light-chain analysis may help identify immunoglobulin light-chain amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for exertional dyspnea. On physical examination, a parasternal impulse is noted at the left sternal border. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard at the second left intercostal space with fixed splitting of the S2. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Ostium secundum atrial septal defect
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for hypertension. He is asymptomatic. A systolic murmur is heard in the left infraclavicular region. Blood pressure is 168/90 mm Hg in both arms. Chest radiograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: An 18-year-old asymptomatic man has a continuous "machinery" murmur beneath the left clavicle that envelops the second heart sound. What is the most likely cause of this murmur?

options.label: A
options.text: Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic regurgitation

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Bicuspid aortic valve with AR : This would typically cause a diastolic murmur, not a continuous murmur.
  • • Option A. Bicuspid aortic valve with AR
  • • Option C. Pulmonary regurgitation : This would cause a diastolic murmur along the left sternal border that increases with inspiration.
  • • Option C. Pulmonary regurgitation
  • • Option D. VSD: This would cause a holosystolic murmur, not a continuous murmur.
  • • Option D. VSD:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Continuous "machinery" murmur is seen in PDA.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with palpitations and syncope. On examination, he has a systolic click with a pansystolic murmur in the left lower sternal border and an elevated JVP. He also complains of intermittent bluish discoloration of face during exercise since childhood. ECG is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. ASD: While ASD can be present in Ebstein's anomaly, it alone does not explain all the clinical features in this case.
  • • Option
  • • A. ASD:
  • • Option B. VSD: VSD presents with a harsh holosystolic murmur but not the other findings in this case.
  • • Option
  • • B. VSD:
  • • Option D. TOF: TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart defect with a different murmur pattern (harsh systolic ejection murmur) and ECG findings.
  • • Option D. TOF:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Very tall (Himalayan) P waves are a hallmark of Ebstein’s anomaly.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy from a rural area in tamilnadu presents with fatigue during physical activity, clubbing, and cyanosis in his feet. His hands appear normal. What is the most likely congenital abnormality?

options.label: A
options.text: Atrial septal defect with shunt reversal

options.label: C
options.text: Patent ductus arteriosus with shunt reversal

options.label: D
options.text: Ventricular septal defect with shunt reversal

questions.correct_answer: C. Patent ductus arteriosus with shunt reversal
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Atrial septal defect with shunt reversal: While ASDs can lead to Eisenmenger syndrome, the cyanosis would be central, affecting both upper and lower extremities.
  • • Option A. Atrial septal defect with shunt reversal:
  • • Option B. D-transposition of the great arteries: This typically presents with severe central cyanosis (nit differential) shortly after birth, not later in childhood.
  • • Option B. D-transposition of the great arteries:
  • • Option D. Ventricular septal defect with shunt reversal: Similar to ASD, VSDs can lead to Eisenmenger syndrome, but cyanosis would be central, not differential.
  • • Option D. Ventricular septal defect with shunt reversal:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Differential cyanosis (lower extremity cyanosis with sparing of the upper extremities) is a hallmark of a PDA with Eisenmenger syndrome.

questions.text: You are performing a right heart catheterization in a 45-year-old man with suspected pulmonary hypertension. You do indeed note elevated pulmonary arterial pressures, with a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 45 mmHg. The patient is not hypoxemic. However, you also note the following oxygen saturations from each cardiac chamber: Superior vena cava—61% Inferior vena cava—65% Right atrium—85% Right ventricle—84% Pulmonary artery—84% You suspect which of the following based on this data?

options.label: A
options.text: Atrial septal defect with left-to-right shunting

options.label: C
options.text: Ventricular septal defect with left-to-right shunting

options.label: D
options.text: Ventricular septal defect with right-to-left shunting

questions.correct_answer: A. Atrial septal defect with left-to-right shunting
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Patent ductus arteriosus: This would cause a step-up in the pulmonary artery saturation, not the right atrium.
  • • Option B. Patent ductus arteriosus:
  • • Option C. Ventricular septal defect with left-to-right shunting: This would cause a step-up in the right ventricle, not the right atrium.
  • • Option C. Ventricular septal defect with left-to-right shunting:
  • • Option D. Ventricular septal defect with right-to-left shunting: This would not cause a step-up in oxygen saturation in any right heart chamber.
  • • Option D. Ventricular septal defect with right-to-left shunting:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ A step-up in oxygen saturation between the vena cavae and the right atrium during right heart catheterization is indicative of ASD.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) disease are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: A mutation in the NOTCH1 gene is responsible for BAV in some families.

options.label: B
options.text: Ascending aortic aneurysm formation occurs commonly among patients with BAV disease.

options.label: C
options.text: BAV has a female to male predominance.

options.label: D
options.text: BAV is the most common congenital heart abnormality.

questions.correct_answer: C. BAV has a female to male predominance.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A . Mutations in NOTCH1 have been linked to some familial cases of BAV.
  • • Option A
  • • Option B . Aortopathy, including ascending aortic aneurysm formation, is a common association with BAV.
  • • Option B
  • • Option D . BAV is the most common congenital heart abnormality, affecting about 0.5-1.4% of the population.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ BAV is the most common congenital heart valve defect.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital cardiovascular abnormalities would provide the highest maternal risk in the setting of pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic diameter <45 mm

options.label: B
options.text: Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return without pulmonary hypertension

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic diameter <45 mm : While a bicuspid aortic valve can be associated with aortic dilation, the risk is lower if the aortic diameter is less than 45 mm.
  • • Option A. Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic diameter <45 mm
  • • Option B. Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return without pulmonary hypertension : This condition is generally well-tolerated and poses a lower risk in pregnancy.
  • • Option B. Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return without pulmonary hypertension
  • • Option D. Systemic right ventricle : While this can be associated with complex congenital heart disease, it does not carry the same immediate risk of aortic complications as severe coarctation.
  • • Option D. Systemic right ventricle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Severe aortic coarctation is a high-risk condition in pregnancy due to the increased risk of aortic dissection or rupture.

questions.text: You are reading an 2D Echo on a 26-year-old with dyspnea and a murmur. You note a mid-septal VSD. You also expect to find dilation of which of the following cardiac chambers?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Left ventricle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Left to right shunts below tricuspid valve usually causes LV dilatation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old non-smoker presents with dyspnea, chest pain, and pulsus paradoxus. Echocardiogram shows a large pericardial effusion and a right atrial mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Atrial myxoma : More common in the left atrium, less likely to cause bloody effusion.
  • • Option A. Atrial myxoma
  • • Option B. Bronchogenic carcinoma : Less likely in a non-smoker, and presentation is not typical.
  • • Option B. Bronchogenic carcinoma
  • • Option D. Papillary fibroelastoma : Usually found on heart valves, not associated with pericardial effusion.
  • • Option D. Papillary fibroelastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiac angiosarcomas are rare malignant cardiac tumors that typically arise within the right atrium and are commonly associated with sanguinous pericardial effusion.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with hypertension presents with acute chest pain, unequal blood pressures in the arms, a diastolic murmur, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Coronary angiography : Not the priority in this acute setting. CT Angiography would have been more appropriate though.
  • • Option A. Coronary angiography
  • • Option B. Intravenous nitroprusside : Used for blood pressure control after the diagnosis is confirmed, but not the definitive treatment.
  • • Option B. Intravenous nitroprusside
  • • Option D. Thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR): Typically used for uncomplicated type B dissections, not type A.
  • • Option D. Thoracic endovascular aortic repair

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with ascending aortic dissection, immediate open aortic repair is imperative to improve survival and reduce morbidity.

questions.text: A 67-year-old smoker presents with dyspnea, pedal edema and exertional chest pain. He is a known diabetic and hypertensive and on medications for the same. ECG shows LBBB on ECG has an EF of 25% in 2D Echo. What is the most appropriate test?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Cardiac MRI : Can be helpful after CAD is ruled out or for assessing myocardial viability.
  • • Option B. Cardiac MRI
  • • Option C. Cardiac PET : Can aid in assessing LV function and evaluating for ischemia. However, given this patient's high likelihood of CAD, cardiac catheterization is the most direct and appropriate modality to assess for CAD.
  • • Option C. Cardiac PET
  • • Option D. Technetium-99m pyrophosphate scintigraphy : Used for diagnosing transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy, not the most likely diagnosis in this case.
  • • Option D. Technetium-99m pyrophosphate scintigraphy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with new-onset heart failure and a high likelihood of coronary artery disease should be evaluated with cardiac catheterization.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is evaluated for sudden-onset dyspnea. Blood pressure is 198/120 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals aortic regurgitation and pulmonary crackles. Emergency chest CT with contrast is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most likely diagnosis is type A aortic dissection. The CT scan with contrast shows a dissection plane extending through the aortic arch (arrow). Type A aortic dissection classically presents with the sudden onset of chest or back pain that has a tearing or ripping quality; however, not all patients will have this symptom. Patients may present with hypertension, syncope, a murmur of aortic regurgitation, or heart failure in the setting of sudden aortic insufficiency. The findings of asymmetric blood pressures in the upper extremities, asymmetric pulses, or pulsus paradoxus should all raise suspicion for acute aortic dissection.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is evaluated during a routine examination. Blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation is performed with firm pressure on the diaphragm at the upper left sternal border. Which of the following best describes the second sound?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • In this patient, auscultation reveals normal splitting of S2 during inspiration. Both components of a split S2 are high-frequency sounds heard best with the diaphragm in the second left intercostal space.
  • • Splitting of S2 represents asynchronous closure of the aortic and pulmonic valves. In the normal adult, splitting varies with the respiratory cycle and is perceived as a single S2 during expiration and a double S2 during inspiration.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is evaluated for hypotension and orthopnea. The neck veins are examined with the patient in a semirecumbent position. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient's neck examination reveals jugular venous distention, reflecting increased right atrial pressure, which is most likely caused by left-sided heart failure. Other causes of jugular venous distension include cardiac tamponade, right ventricular failure, and massive pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is evaluated for exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. Blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation over the apical impulse is performed with light pressure on the bell. Which of the following best describes the acoustic events at the apex?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) S1 + S2 + S3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • The acoustic events at the apex are best described as S1 + S2 + S3. An S3 is heard in this patient. An S3 is a low-frequency, early diastolic sound best heard with the bell of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex. It may be perceived as a double S2. Positioning the patient in the left lateral decubitus position will facilitate the identification of an S3. An S3 is often heard in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction but can also be present in volume overload states, such as valvular regurgitation, shunt lesions, or late pregnancy. An S3 can also represent a normal finding in children or highly trained athletes.
  • • An S4 is also a low-frequency diastolic sound, but it occurs in late diastole and thus may be perceived as a double S1.
  • • Both components of a split S2 are high-frequency sounds heard best with the diaphragm in the second left intercostal space. Splitting of the S2 represents asynchronous closure of the aortic and pulmonic valves. In the normal adult, splitting varies with the respiratory cycle and is perceived as a single S2 during expiration and a double S2 during inspiration. Paradoxical splitting of S2 is characterized by audible splitting during expiration and a single S2 during inspiration. It is often associated with aortic stenosis but does not differentiate mild from severe aortic stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is seen on this CT angiogram?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • The CT angiogram shows a Stanford type B aortic dissection arising immediately distal to the take-off of the left subclavian artery and extending to the level of the common iliac arteries. Type B aortic dissections are usually treated with medical therapy that controls blood pressure. β-Blockers are the initial agents of choice. Invasive treatment for type B aortic dissections is reserved for patients with occlusion of a major aortic branch with visceral or limb ischemia, progressive dilation or expansion on medical therapy, or a large penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical manifestations is most likely associated with the findings seen on this CT angiogram?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • The findings seen on this CT angiogram are most likely associated with livedo reticularis. Livedo reticularis is a subtle, lacy network of faintly pink or bluish red vessels, usually seen on the lower legs due to altered blood flow through cutaneous vessels. This CT angiogram shows extensive atherosclerotic disease scattered throughout the central vasculature. Plaques are heavily concentrated in the proximal descending aorta, causing visible narrowing. Aortic atherosclerotic plaques are a significant source of systemic emboli. Emboli from aortic plaques may be thrombotic or atheromatous. Thromboembolism occurs when an atherosclerotic plaque becomes unstable and ruptures, exposing thrombogenic factors that lead to clot formation. Thromboemboli that arise from plaques tend to be single and lodge in small or medium arteries, causing transient ischemic attack, stroke, kidney infarction, intestinal ischemia, or limb ischemia. Atheroemboli result from release of fragments of plaque (such as cholesterol crystals) that tend to lodge more diffusely in smaller arterial beds in different organs; they may result in conditions such as livedo reticularis, “blue toe” syndrome, and retinal or kidney ischemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the strongest predictor of Cardiovascular disease (CVD) incidence and subsequent mortality due to CVD?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. TC/HDL (Total Cholesterol to HDL ratio): While this ratio provides some information about cardiovascular risk, it is not as strong a predictor as LDL cholesterol alone.
  • • Option A. TC/HDL (Total Cholesterol to HDL ratio):
  • • Option B. hs-CRP (High-sensitivity C-reactive protein): hs-CRP is a marker of inflammation, which can contribute to the development of CVD. However, it is not as directly linked to CVD risk as LDL cholesterol. It has a high negative predictive value with regards to CVD but can be elevated in inflammatory states, hence not very specific.
  • • Option B. hs-CRP (High-sensitivity C-reactive protein):
  • • Option D. HDL (High-density lipoprotein cholesterol): Higher levels of HDL are protective, but they are not as strong a predictor of risk as LDL cholesterol.
  • • Option D. HDL (High-density lipoprotein cholesterol):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ LDL cholesterol is the primary target for lipid-lowering therapy in the prevention and management of CVD due to its strong association with CVD incidence and mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following imaging modalities is best for assessing coronary plaque morphology?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. IVUS (Intravascular Ultrasound): While IVUS provides valuable information about plaque burden and vessel size, its resolution is not as high as OCT, limiting its ability to characterize plaque morphology in detail.
  • • Option A. IVUS (Intravascular Ultrasound):
  • • Option C. Coronary Angiography: Angiography is a luminal imaging technique that only shows the outline of the vessel lumen. It cannot visualize plaque components within the vessel wall.
  • • Option C. Coronary Angiography:
  • • Option D. CT Coronary Calcium Scoring: This non-invasive technique quantifies the amount of calcium in coronary arteries, a marker of atherosclerosis. However, it does not provide detailed information about plaque morphology or composition.
  • • Option
  • • D. CT Coronary Calcium Scoring:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ OCT is the gold standard imaging modality for assessing coronary plaque morphology due to its superior resolution, which allows for detailed visualization of plaque components and aids in risk assessment and treatment planning.

questions.text: A 68-year-old gentleman is brought into your emergency department after a syncopal episode. ECG shows a regular broad complex tachycardia with no apparent P waves. With regard to the JVP waveform, which of these features would you expect to see?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Giant v waves: Seen in tricuspid regurgitation, not VT.
  • • Option A. Giant v waves:
  • • Option C. Prominent x descent: This is a normal finding in the JVP waveform.
  • • Option C. Prominent x descent:
  • • Option D. Slow y descent: Seen in constrictive pericarditis or cardiac tamponade.
  • • Option D. Slow y descent:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Irregular cannon a waves in the JVP is a sign of AV dissociation, which is commonly seen in ventricular tachycardia and complete

questions.text: An 18-year-old high school student has a syncopal episode while playing basketball. On physical examination, he has a rapid carotid upstroke and a loud systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. ECG and 2D echo showed LVH. What maneuver is expected to decrease the murmur?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Squat-to-stand maneuver: This maneuver increases preload (the volume of blood returning to the heart). In HCM, increased preload can worsen the outflow tract obstruction, leading to an increase in the murmur's intensity.
  • • Option A. Squat-to-stand maneuver:
  • • Option C. Valsalva maneuver: This maneuver decreases preload. In HCM, this can initially worsen the outflow tract obstruction, leading to a louder murmur. However, in later phases of the maneuver, the murmur may decrease due to decreased left ventricular volume.
  • • Option C. Valsalva maneuver:
  • • Option D. Amyl nitrate inhalation: This maneuver primarily decreases afterload. While it can decrease the intensity of the murmur in HCM, it is not as effective as the hand grip maneuver.
  • • Option D. Amyl nitrate inhalation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HCM has a dynamic LVOT obstruction and the murmur correlates with the degree of LVOT obstruction.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes for a routine follow-up visit. His physical examination is normal, but an echocardiogram reveals a 1-cm mass attached to the mitral valve with a stalk. The mass is independently mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Bacterial endocarditis : Usually presents with fever, chills, and a new or changing murmur.
  • • Option A. Bacterial endocarditis
  • • Option B. Left atrial myxoma : Larger and usually attached to the atrial septum, not the valve.
  • • Option B. Left atrial myxoma
  • • Option C. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE): Associated with malignancy or hypercoagulable states, not the typical appearance of PFEs.
  • • Option C. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Typical presentation of papillary fibroelastoma on echocardiography → a small, mobile mass attached to a valve by a stalk.

questions.text: An 18-year-old asymptomatic basketball player has come for routine evaluation. On examination he has a brisk carotid upstroke and grade 3/6 systolic murmur in the left sternal border. Echocardiogram showing asymmetric septal hypertrophy (18mm), systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve, and a resting LVOT gradient of 30 mmHg. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Advise the patient that he should not play basketball

questions.correct_answer: A. Advise the patient that he should not play basketball
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Beta-blockers : May be used to treat symptoms of HF in HCM, but do not eliminate the risk of sudden cardiac death in athletes.
  • • Option B. Beta-blockers
  • • Option C. Alcohol septal ablation : Considered for symptomatic patients with severe LVOT obstruction and have failed initial medical therapy.
  • • Option C. Alcohol septal ablation
  • • Option D. ICD placement : Patients with HCM should be considered for implantable cardioverter-defibrillator therapy if they have any of the following risk factors for sudden cardiac death: (1) massive myocardial hypertrophy (wall thickness ≥30 mm), (2) previous cardiac arrest due to ventricular arrhythmia, (3) blunted blood pressure response or hypotension during exercise, (4) unexplained syncope, (5) nonsustained ventricular tachycardia on ambulatory ECG and (6) family history of sudden death due to HCM.
  • • Option D. ICD placement
  • • An ICD should not be placed solely for the purpose of allowing a patient to participate in high-intensity sports.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Athletes with a probable or unequivocal diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may participate in competitive sports that are considered static and low intensity.

questions.text: A 48-year-old asymptomatic woman comes for a routine health check-up. On examination she has a grade 2/6 midsystolic murmur localized to the left sternal border that diminishes with standing. Other reports including ECG and chest xray were normal. What is the next step?
questions.correct_answer: D. Routine clinical follow-up without imaging
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Cardiac MRI : Unnecessary for an asymptomatic patient with a benign murmur.
  • • Option A. Cardiac MRI
  • • Option B. TEE : Invasive and not warranted in this scenario.
  • • Option B. TEE
  • • Option C. TTE : Not necessary unless the murmur is associated with other symptoms or abnormalities on physical examination.
  • • Option C. TTE

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Short, soft systolic murmurs (grade <3) that are well localized to the left sternal border and are not associated with symptoms often do not require further investigation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man with short stature, hypertelorism, and neck webbing has a loud systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border and a click that is heard better with expiration. Which genetic disorder is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Down syndrome : More commonly associated with atrioventricular septal defects.
  • • Option A. Down syndrome
  • • Option B. Marfan syndrome : Associated with aortic root dilation and other skeletal abnormalities.
  • • Option B. Marfan syndrome
  • • Option D. Turner syndrome : Sex chromosome disorder seen in females, not males.
  • • Option D. Turner syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Noonan syndrome is commonly associated with congenital cardiac lesions, including pulmonary stenosis.

questions.text: Falsely low BNP (B-type natriuretic peptide) values can be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Advanced age: BNP levels tend to increase with age, so falsely low values are less likely in older individuals.
  • • Option A. Advanced age:
  • • Option C. Female gender: While there may be slight gender differences in BNP levels, it is not a major factor in causing falsely low values.
  • • Option C. Female gender:
  • • Option D. Smoking: Smoking is not known to significantly affect BNP levels.
  • • Option D. Smoking:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obesity, constrictive pericarditis, cardiac tamponade and rarely flash pulmonary edema may be associated with lower than expected BNP levels.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following rhythm. His BP is 120/80 mm Hg and his pulse rate is 150/min. The following manoeuvre is performed. What is the manoeuvre?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Standard Valsalva: The standard Valsalva manoeuvre alone is less effective than the REVERT manoeuvre in terminating SVTs.
  • • Option A. Standard Valsalva:
  • • Option C. Castell’s manoeuvre: Used fir splenic percussion and not related to cardiology.
  • • Option C. Castell’s manoeuvre:
  • • Option D. Modified squat manoeuvre: There is no such manoeuvre.
  • • Option D. Modified squat manoeuvre:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ REVERT manoeuvre is more effective in terminating paroxysmal SVTs compared to standard Valsalva manoeuvre.

questions.text: A patient with chronic heart failure presents with dyspnea on exertion and fatigue. You ask the patient to do Valsalva and you notice the blood pressure tracing as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Increased sympathetic nervous system activity: This would typically lead to an exaggerated overshoot response.
  • • Option A. Increased sympathetic nervous system activity:
  • • Option C. Increased parasympathetic nervous system activity: This would result in a more pronounced decrease in blood pressure during the strain phase but not necessarily affect the overshoot.
  • • Option C. Increased parasympathetic nervous system activity:
  • • Option D. Impaired diastolic function: Usually results in a square wave response.
  • • Option D. Impaired diastolic function:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the normal physiological response to the Valsalva maneuver and recognize the absence of the overshoot response as a potential sign of impaired systolic function in heart failure.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with dyspnea, fatigue, and peripheral edema. On examination, you observe the JVP as shown in the video and a pansystolic murmur in the left sternal border. This finding is called as:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Bernheim effect: This refers to the displacement of the interventricular septum towards the left ventricle in patients with right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • • Option B. Bernheim effect:
  • • Option C. Muller's sign: This is the systolic pulsation of the uvula seen in severe aortic regurgitation.
  • • Option C. Muller's sign:
  • • Option D. Brockenbrough effect: This refers to the paradoxical decrease in pulse pressure in the Post-VPC impulse, seen in HOCM.
  • • Option D. Brockenbrough effect:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize Lancisi's sign as a clinical manifestation of tricuspid regurgitation, characterized by a giant cv wave in the JVP coinciding with ventricular systole.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with palpitations. You examine his JVP and you see as what is shown in the video below. His pulse rate is 150/min. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Complete heart block: This would typically cause bradycardia (slow heart rate) and irregular cannon a waves.
  • • Option A. Complete heart block:
  • • Option B. Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT): SVTs (like AVNRT) tend to produce regular cannon ‘a’ waves.
  • • Option B. Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT):
  • • Option D. WPW syndrome: WPW can cause SVTs (like AVRT) which sometimes can produce regular cannon ‘a’ waves.
  • • Option D. WPW syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Irregular cannon ‘a’ waves in the JVP is a hallmark of AV dissociation and it is commonly seen in complete heart block and VT.

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady presents with ascites, elevated JVP, and pedal edema. Her JVP is shown in the video. All of the following can be the cause except?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Constrictive pericarditis: The rigid pericardium restricts ventricular filling, leading to right heart failure and Kussmaul's sign. Classic cause of Kussmaul’s sign.
  • • Option A.
  • • Constrictive pericarditis:
  • • Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: The stiff ventricles in this condition also impair filling, causing right heart failure and Kussmaul's sign.
  • • Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy:
  • • Option C. Tricuspid stenosis: This directly obstructs blood flow from the right atrium to the right ventricle, leading to elevated right atrial pressure, JVP elevation, and Kussmaul's sign.
  • • Option C. Tricuspid stenosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Kussmaul's sign (increased JVP with inspiration) is a specific finding in conditions that impair right ventricular filling, such as constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and tricuspid stenosis.

questions.text: All of the following can cause paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound except?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. LBBB (Left Bundle Branch Block): Delays left ventricular activation and thus aortic valve closure.
  • • Option A. LBBB (Left Bundle Branch Block):
  • • Option C. RV pacing: Delays right ventricular activation and thus pulmonic valve closure, leading to A2 preceding P2 on expiration (similar to paradoxical splitting).
  • • Option C. RV pacing:
  • • Option D. HOCM (Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy): Can cause delayed left ventricular emptying and aortic valve closure.
  • • Option D. HOCM (Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Classic causes of paradoxical splitting are LBBB, severe AS/HOCM and RV pacing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with pounding sensation in the chest for the last 1 hour. On examination you notice the JVP to be elevated and it shown in the video below. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ventricular ectopics: Ventricular ectopics can cause irregular cannon a waves but not regular ones.
  • • Option A. Ventricular ectopics:
  • • Option C. Tricuspid regurgitation: While tricuspid regurgitation can cause prominent v waves in the JVP, it does not typically cause cannon a waves.
  • • Option C. Tricuspid regurgitation:
  • • Option D. Complete heart block: Complete heart block usually causes irregular cannon a waves due to AV dissociation.
  • • Option D. Complete heart block:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical significance of regular cannon a waves in the JVP and their association with AVNRT.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnosis based on the pressure tracing shown in the image.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis: Gradient decreases with Valsalva and post VPC.
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis:
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation: Does not exhibit bronckenbrough effect.
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation:
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation: Does not exhibit bronckenbrough effect.
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brockenbrough effect is a hallmark of HOCM.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis based on the pulse waveform shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ventricular Bigeminy: Associated with pulsus bigeminy.
  • • Option A. Ventricular Bigeminy:
