  • • Option B. Aortic Regurgitation: Usually associated with bounding and collapsing (water hammer) pulse. Sometimes can produce pulsus bisferians (in severe cases) but does not have the spike and dome appearance like that of HOCM.
  • • Option B. Aortic Regurgitation:
  • • Option D. Aortic Stenosis: Aortic stenosis typically presents with a slow-rising and delayed pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus).
  • • Option D. Aortic Stenosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulsus bisferians can be seen in HOCM, AR and sometimes AS + AR but the spike and dome appearance is typical of HOCM.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of recently diagnosed lymphoma presents with dyspnea and diaphoresis. Blood pressure is 70/60 mm Hg, heart rate is 110 beats/min, and her radial pulse becomes difficult to palpate at times, especially during inspiration. You see the monitor and notice the rhythm as shown in the video. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute anterior myocardial infarction: While MI can cause hypotension and tachycardia, it is less likely to cause pulsus paradoxus or electrical alternans.
  • • Option A. Acute anterior myocardial infarction:
  • • Option B. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbation: COPD exacerbation can cause dyspnea and tachycardia, but not the other findings in this case.
  • • Option B. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbation:
  • • Option C. Myocardial amyloidosis: Amyloidosis can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy, but it is a less likely cause of acute tamponade in this patient with a recent lymphoma diagnosis.
  • • Option C. Myocardial amyloidosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Classic clinical presentation of cardiac tamponade is hypotension, tachycardia, pulsus paradoxus, and electrical alternans in ECG.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with severe shortness of breath. You are attending him and notice the pulse and ECG tracing as shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Cardiac Tamponade: Cardiac tamponade can cause pulsus paradoxus and electrical alternans (not pulsus alternans).
  • • Option B. Cardiac Tamponade:
  • • Option C. Septic shock: Septic shock usually results in a bounding pulse. Sometimes, it is associated with a. dicrotic pulse.
  • • Option C. Septic shock:
  • • Option D. Digitalis toxicity: Digitalis toxicity causes pulsus bigeminy and not alternans.
  • • Option D. Digitalis toxicity:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize pulsus alternans as a clinical sign of severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction and understand its underlying pathophysiology.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, now with a new diagnosis of diabetes mellitus, presents with elevated blood pressure (140/90 mmHg), total cholesterol (250 mg/dL), and hemoglobin A1c (6.6%). Which risk factor confers the highest risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Diastolic blood pressure of 90 mm Hg

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B, C, D : A diastolic blood pressure of 90 mm Hg, HDL cholesterol level of 30 mg/dL (0.78 mmol/L) and total cholesterol level of 250 mg/dL (6.47 mmol/L) have a relatively small effect on 10-year ASCVD risk compared with the presence of diabetes.
  • • Option B, C, D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with diabetes mellitus have a 2-4x increased risk for CV disease, with more than two thirds of patients with diabetes eventually dying of heart disease.

questions.text: All of the following can produce the murmur depicted in the video except?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): This is a persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery, leading to a continuous left-to-right shunt and a continuous "machinery murmur."
  • • Option A. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA):
  • • Option B. Lutemacher syndrome: This is a combination of an atrial septal defect (ASD) and mitral stenosis creating a continuous increase in LA → RA pressure gradient resulting in a continuous murmur.
  • • Option B. Lutemacher syndrome:
  • • Option D. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm: This can create a fistula between the aorta and right heart chambers, leading to a continuous shunt and murmur.
  • • Option D. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aortic regurgitation typically results in an early diastolic murmur.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of a soft first heart sound except?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Calcified valves: Calcification of the mitral valve leaflets can make them rigid and less mobile, leading to a softer S1.
  • • Option A. Calcified valves:
  • • Option B. Mitral regurgitation: In some cases of mitral regurgitation, the mitral valve may not close completely, resulting in a softer S1.
  • • Option B. Mitral regurgitation:
  • • Option C. Heart failure: Reduced left ventricular contractility in heart failure can lead to less forceful closure of the mitral valve and a softer S1.
  • • Option C. Heart failure:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperdynamic states are associated with loud S1.

questions.text: All of the following can result in mid-diastolic murmur except?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Complete heart block: Can result in a mid-diastolic murmur (called Rytand’s murmur)
  • • Option A. Complete heart block:
  • • Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Severe aortic regurgitation can cause a mid-diastolic murmur known as the Austin Flint murmur. This occurs due to the regurgitant jet striking the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, causing it to vibrate and create turbulence.
  • • Option B. Aortic regurgitation:
  • • Option C. Acute rheumatic fever: Can result in mitral valvulitis resulting in turbulent blood flow and a mid-diastolic murmur (Carey Coomb’s murmur).
  • • Option C. Acute rheumatic fever:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulmonary regurgitation is associated with an early diastolic murmur.

questions.text: A 45-year-old asymptomatic man is found to have a grade II diastolic murmur on routine physical examination. His ECG and chest X-ray are normal. What is the next best step in evaluation?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac MRI : Offers excellent visualization but is typically reserved for more complex cases or when echocardiography is inconclusive.
  • • Option A. Cardiac MRI
  • • Option B. Carotid ultrasound : Not relevant for the evaluation of a cardiac murmur.
  • • Option B. Carotid ultrasound
  • • Option C. No further workup : A diastolic murmur always requires further investigation.
  • • Option C. No further workup

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A diastolic murmur is always pathological and should be evaluated with echocardiography to assess for underlying structural heart disease.

questions.text: Mr. Tamilvanan, a 67-year-old man, presents with symptoms of heart failure. You are assessing his volume status using JVP examination. Which statement is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The vertical distance between the top of the jugular venous pulsation and the sternal angle accurately measures central venous pressure (CVP).

options.label: B
options.text: The angle of inclination is irrelevant when measuring JVP.

options.label: C
options.text: Normally, JVP rises with inspiration due to increased right heart filling.

options.label: D
options.text: Venous pulsations above the clavicle in the sitting position are abnormal.

questions.correct_answer: D. Venous pulsations above the clavicle in the sitting position are abnormal.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . The vertical distance between the top of the JVP and the sternal angle underestimates CVP, and the measurement is affected by body size and patient position.
  • • Option A
  • • Option B. The angle of inclination is important, as it affects the hydrostatic pressure in the jugular veins.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Normally, the JVP falls with inspiration due to decreased intrathoracic pressure. A rise in JVP with inspiration (Kussmaul's sign) is seen in constrictive pericarditis.
  • • Option C.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Jugular venous pulsations above the clavicle in the sitting position are abnormal and indicative of elevated central venous pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding blood pressure measurements?

options.label: A
options.text: SBP increases and DBP decreases when measured in more distal arteries.

options.label: B
options.text: SBP in the legs are usually as much as 20 mmHg lower than arm blood pressures.

options.label: C
options.text: The difference in blood pressure measured in both arms should be less than 20 mmHg.

options.label: D
options.text: Using a BP cuff that is too small will result in a marked underestimation of the true BP.

questions.correct_answer: A. SBP increases and DBP decreases when measured in more distal arteries.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Systolic leg blood pressures are actually higher than arm pressures, not lower.
  • • Option B
  • • Option C . The difference in blood pressure between arms should be less than 10 mmHg, not 20 mmHg.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D . Using a too-small cuff leads to overestimation of blood pressure, not underestimation.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ So many things have to be considered while taking BP recordings!

questions.text: What is the cardiac axis marked by ‘?’ in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Right Axis: From +90° to 180 °
  • • Option A. Right Axis:
  • • Option B. Northwest Axis: -90 ° to 180 °
  • • Option B. Northwest Axis:
  • • Option C. Normal Axis: -30 ° to 90 ° (or 100 ° )
  • • Option C. Normal Axis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Axis determination is important in exams!

questions.text: All of the following diseases are associated with the development of cardiac conduction disease EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Lyme disease: Cardiac involvement in Lyme disease can lead to AV block.
  • • Option B. Lyme disease:
  • • Option C. Syphilis: This can lead to aortitis and subsequent damage to the conducting system.
  • • Option C. Syphilis:
  • • Option D. Systemic lupus erythematosus: This autoimmune disease can cause inflammation in the heart, including the conduction system.
  • • Option D. Systemic lupus erythematosus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypothyroidism (not hyperthyroidism) causes conduction system abnormalities. Hyperthyroidism is associated with sinus tachycardia and AF.

questions.text: Ms. Anitha, a 24-year-old woman, presents with postural light-headedness and palpitations after a recent upper respiratory illness. Upon standing for 2 minutes, her heart rate increases to 135 beats/min with no change in blood pressure. Which of the following is a reasonable therapeutic option for her?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Fluid restriction: This would worsen the hypovolemia and exacerbate the symptoms of POTS.
  • • Option A. Fluid restriction:
  • • Option B. Upright Yoga: While exercise can be beneficial in the long term, it may initially worsen symptoms in POTS patients due to increased demands on the cardiovascular system.
  • • Option B. Upright Yoga:
  • • Option C. Furosemide: This is a diuretic that would further decrease blood volume and worsen symptoms.
  • • Option C. Furosemide:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ POTS is characterized by symptomatic sinus tachycardia that occurs with postural change from a supine position to standing. The sinus rate increases by 30 beats/min or to >120 beats/min within 10 minutes of standing and in the absence of hypotension.

questions.text: After a common heart transplant operation, a portion of which donor heart chamber will remain in the donor?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • The most common contemporary cardiac transplant operation is referred to as a “bicaval” orthotopic cardiac transplant that mimics the natural anatomic position. In this operation, the donor and recipient SVC and IVC are connected as are the aortic and pulmonary great vessels. The left atrium of the recipient retains its roof, including the draining pulmonary veins, and the donor left atrium is then sutured to the retained atrial tissue. This technique maintains function of the donor right atrium, which is important for governing early postoperative right heart output, and may prevent atrial arrhythmias.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a standard heart transplantation procedure, the left atrium of the recipient retains its roof, including the draining pulmonary veins, and the donor left atrium is then sutured to the retained atrial tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an early diastolic sound?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. S3: Early diastolic sound.
  • • Option A. S3:
  • • Option C. OS: Early diastolic sound.
  • • Option C. OS:
  • • Option D. Pericardial knock: Early diastolic sound.
  • • Option D. Pericardial knock:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ S3, OS, pericardial knock and tumour plop (seen in atrial myxoma) are early diastolic sounds, while S4 is a late diastolic sound.

questions.text: Mr. Farooq, a 45-year-old man, presents with progressive dyspnea. PFT and CT chest are normal. Echo shows features of pulmonary hypertension and his LVEF is 65%. His cardiac catheterization reports are shown. RA pressure- 10 mmHg PA pressure - 55/35 (mean = 42) mmHg PCWP - 34 mmHg LVEDP - 34 mmHg Cardiac output - 4.5 L/min PVR - 1.8 Wood unit What is the most likely cause of his pulmonary hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Chronic lung disease : Normal PFT and CT chest make chronic lung disease unlikely.
  • • Option A
  • • Chronic lung disease
  • • Option B. Mitral stenosis : Elevated LVEDP is unlikely in mitral stenosis. Also, mitral stenosis patients have a gradient between LVEDP and PCWP. Identical LVEDP and PCWP rules out mitral stenosis.
  • • Option B. Mitral stenosis
  • • Option D. Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension: The elevated PCWP rules out idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension.
  • • Option D. Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In the presence of elevated PCWP equal to LVEDP and normal LV systolic function, consider HFpEF as the cause of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: You are assessing a patient with an aortic aneurysm. You observe hypertelorism, a bifid uvula, and "corkscrew" carotids on imaging. You suspect Loeys-Dietz syndrome. Which protein's gene mutation is responsible for the syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator : Mutations in this gene cause cystic fibrosis.
  • • Option A. Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator
  • • Option B. Fibrillin-1 : Mutations in this gene cause Marfan syndrome.
  • • Option B. Fibrillin-1
  • • Option C. STK11 gene : Mutations in this gene cause Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
  • • Option C. STK11 gene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Loeys-Dietz syndrome is caused by mutations in the genes encoding TGF-βr.

questions.text: Which of the following rheumatologic diseases is associated with a risk for aortic aneurysms?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Various rheumatologic diseases have increased risk of aortic aneurysms.

questions.text: All of the following are appropriate therapeutic steps for varicose veins EXCEPT:

options.label: C
options.text: Frequent elevation of the lower extremities.

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Avoid prolonged standing: Prolonged standing increases pressure in the veins of the legs, worsening varicose veins.
  • • Option B. Avoid prolonged standing:
  • • Option C. Frequent elevation of the lower extremities: Elevating the legs helps reduce pressure in the veins and improves blood flow back to the heart.
  • • Option C. Frequent elevation of the lower extremities:
  • • Option D. Graduated compression stockings: These stockings apply pressure to the legs, helping to improve blood flow and reduce swelling.
  • • Option D. Graduated compression stockings:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Aspirin is not a standard treatment for varicose veins.

questions.text: All of the following are reasonable therapeutic options for chronic lymphedema EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Frequent leg elevation: Elevating the affected limb helps reduce swelling by promoting lymphatic drainage.
  • • Option B. Frequent leg elevation:
  • • Option C. Intermittent pneumatic compression devices: These devices use air pressure to massage the limb and promote lymphatic flow.
  • • Option C. Intermittent pneumatic compression devices:
  • • Option D. Liposuction: In some cases, liposuction can be used to remove excess fat and reduce the size of the affected limb. Liposuction may be particularly useful in post-mastectomy lymphedema.
  • • Option D. Liposuction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diuretic therapy is ineffective and contraindicated in lymphedema.

questions.text: Which of the statements regarding chronic venous disease is true?

options.label: A
options.text: More men than women suffer from varicose veins.

options.label: B
options.text: More men than women suffer from chronic venous insufficiency with edema.

options.label: C
options.text: More than 50% of patients over 70 years old have chronic venous insufficiency.

options.label: D
options.text: Most patients with chronic venous insufficiency will develop venous ulcers.

questions.correct_answer: B. More men than women suffer from chronic venous insufficiency with edema.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. More men than women suffer from varicose veins: This is incorrect; varicose veins are more common in women.
  • • Option A. More men than women suffer from varicose veins:
  • • Option C. More than 50% of patients over 70 years old have chronic venous insufficiency: The prevalence in this age group is closer to 10%.
  • • Option C. More than 50% of patients over 70 years old have chronic venous insufficiency:
  • • Option D. Most patients with chronic venous insufficiency will develop venous ulcers: Only about 20% of patients with chronic venous insufficiency develop venous ulcers.
  • • Option D. Most patients with chronic venous insufficiency will develop venous ulcers:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Varicose veins are more common in women than in men.

questions.text: In a patient with bacterial endocarditis, which of the following echocardiographic lesions is most likely to lead to embolization?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 11-mm mitral valve vegetation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Although any valvular vegetation can embolize, vegetations located on the mitral valve and vegetations >10 mm are at greatest risk of embolizing. Of the choices, options B, C, and D are large enough to increase the risk of embolization.
  • • Hematogenously seeded infection from an embolized vegetation may involve any organ, but particularly affects those organs with the highest blood flow. They are seen in up to 50% of patients with endocarditis. Tricuspid lesions will lead to pulmonary septic emboli, which is common in injection drug users. Mitral and aortic lesions can lead to embolic infections in the skin, spleen, kidneys, meninges, and skeletal system. A dreaded neurologic complication is mycotic aneurysm, focal dilations of arteries at points in the arterial wall that have been weakened by infection in the vasa vasorum or septic emboli, leading to hemorrhage.
  • • Education Objective :
  • • Education Objective
  • • :
  • • Mitral vegetations >10 mm are at greatest risk of embolization

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with a history of bioprosthetic aortic valve replacement presents with intermittent fever and dyspnea 3 years after the procedure. TTE is normal. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac CT : Less sensitive than TEE for detecting vegetations.
  • • Option A. Cardiac CT
  • • Option B. Cardiac MRI : Not the first-line imaging modality for PVE.
  • • Option B. Cardiac MRI
  • • Option D. No further testing : Inappropriate given the suspicion for PVE.
  • • Option D. No further testing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In patients with suspected infective endocarditis, transthoracic echocardiography is recommended as the initial imaging choice in most clinical situations.
  • ➤ TEE is the preferred imaging modality to evaluate for PVE when TTE is inconclusive or if complications have developed or are clinically suspected or if intracardiac device leads are present, transesophageal echocardiography is recommended.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is evaluated for recurrent pericarditis. He has had two prior episodes, both successfully treated with ibuprofen and colchicine. His current symptoms include fever, pulsus paradoxus, a pericardial friction rub, and widespread ST-segment elevation on ECG. Echocardiogram shows a small pericardial effusion without tamponade. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Anakinra : This is an interleukin-1 receptor antagonist used for refractory cases of recurrent pericarditis that have not responded to other treatments.
  • • Option A. Anakinra
  • • Option B. Colchicine and IVIG : This combination is also used for refractory cases, but glucocorticoids should be added first.
  • • Option B. Colchicine and IVIG
  • • Option C. Ibuprofen alone : Unlikely to be effective for recurrent pericarditis, especially since it has been used previously.
  • • Option C. Ibuprofen alone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In patients with recurrent pericarditis initially treated with both colchicine and an NSAID, the addition of a glucocorticoid should be considered.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man had an atrial septal defect (ASD) closure one year ago. He is now scheduled for tooth extraction and periodontal cleaning. The dentist recommended a nil per oral (NPO) 8 hours prior to the procedure. What is the choice for IE prophylaxis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A), B), C): These are antibiotics used for endocarditis prophylaxis but are not indicated in this case.
  • • A), B), C):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endocarditis prophylaxis is not routinely recommended for dental procedures in patients with repaired ASDs unless there are specific high-risk features.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea, cough, weight loss, and pulsus paradoxus. Physical exam reveals jugular venous distention, distant heart sounds, and crackles. Chest X-ray shows a large right upper lobe mass and an enlarged cardiac silhouette. What is the next test?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. CT-guided needle biopsy : May be needed later to assess the lung mass, but not the immediate priority.
  • • Option A. CT-guided needle biopsy
  • • Option B. Fiberoptic bronchoscopy : May be useful for evaluating the lung mass, but not the priority in this unstable patient.
  • • Option B. Fiberoptic bronchoscopy
  • • Option C. PET/CT : May be useful for staging malignancy, but not the immediate priority.
  • • Option C. PET/CT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Findings suggesting cardiac tamponade include pulsus paradoxus, tachycardia, distant heart sounds, and occasionally an enlarged silhouette on CXR.
  • ➤ Echocardiography is an essential tool in the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade because it defines the presence, distribution, and relative volume of pericardial fluid.

questions.text: A patient evaluated for cough is found to have an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest radiography. He is suspected of having pericardial effusion. Ultrasonography is performed with the probe placed in the subxiphoid area. The results are shown. Which of the following is the most likely interpretation of this study?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. No pericardial effusion: This option is incorrect because the ultrasound clearly demonstrates the presence of a significant anechoic space around the heart, indicating a pericardial effusion.
  • • Option B. No pericardial effusion:
  • • Option C. LV dilatation: Left ventricular (LV) dilatation is not indicated by the findings described in this scenario. The primary abnormality is the pericardial effusion, not an intrinsic abnormality of the left ventricle.
  • • Option C. LV dilatation:
  • • Option D. Indeterminate study : This option is incorrect because the ultrasound findings are definitive for a large pericardial effusion. There is no indication that the study is inconclusive or indeterminate.
  • • Option D. Indeterminate study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A large pericardial effusion is characterized by the accumulation of fluid around the heart, visible as an anechoic space on ultrasound. It can lead to cardiac tamponade, a life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and management.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with SLE presents with progressive dyspnea, fatigue, chest fullness, and bilateral peripheral edema. She is febrile and her JVP is elevated. ECG is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Constrictive pericarditis : Although it can present with similar symptoms, it usually has a more insidious onset and does not typically cause electrical alternans on ECG.
  • • Option B. Constrictive pericarditis
  • • Option C. Pulmonary embolism : Can cause dyspnea and elevated JVP, but it would not typically present with electrical alternans.
  • • Option C. Pulmonary embolism
  • • Option D. Pulmonary hypertension : Less likely in the absence of lung disease or right heart failure.
  • • Option D. Pulmonary hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Electrical alternans is a hallmark of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-week history of fever and malaise. Nail findings show splinter hemorrhages. Which of the following is the next appropriate step?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Urine cultures: While urine cultures may be helpful in identifying a urinary tract infection, they are not the primary diagnostic test for suspected IE.
  • • Option B. Urine cultures:
  • • Option C. CT scan of the chest: A CT scan might be helpful in later stages to assess for complications of IE, such as embolic events, but blood cultures are the first step.
  • • Option C. CT scan of the chest:
  • • Option D. CSF analysis: CSF analysis is used to diagnose infections of the central nervous system, not IE.
  • • Option D. CSF analysis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Splinter hemorrhages in the setting of fever and malaise raise the suspicion of infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-day history of fever, malaise, and heart murmur. Today, crops of nonpainful cutaneous lesions have appeared on his feet as shown. Given the diagnosis, the patient is at risk of all of the following except?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Intracranial hemorrhage: Septic emboli from IE can lodge in the brain, causing intracranial hemorrhage.
  • • Option A. Intracranial hemorrhage:
  • • Option B. Stroke: Septic emboli can also cause ischemic stroke.
  • • Option B. Stroke:
  • • Option C. Heart failure: Valve damage from IE can lead to heart failure.
  • • Option C. Heart failure:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Aortic complications are uncommon in endocarditis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is evaluated for chronic right-sided heart failure. Chest radiographs are shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension: This condition involves pulmonary artery obstruction due to organized clots, leading to increased pulmonary artery pressure and right-sided heart failure. However, it would not typically present with pericardial calcification on chest radiographs.
  • • Option A. Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension:
  • • Option C. Primary hyperparathyroidism: While primary hyperparathyroidism can cause hypercalcemia and possibly lead to calcifications in various tissues, it is not typically associated with pericardial calcification or the symptoms of chronic right-sided heart failure.
  • • Option C. Primary hyperparathyroidism:
  • • Option D. Restrictive cardiomyopathy : Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic dysfunction due to myocardial stiffness but does not involve pericardial calcification. The imaging findings and clinical presentation are more consistent with constrictive pericarditis.
  • • Option D. Restrictive cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by pericardial thickening and calcification that leads to impaired cardiac filling and chronic right-sided heart failure. Radiographic evidence of pericardial calcification is a key diagnostic clue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-week history of subjective fever and malaise. A grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur that increases with inspiration is present at the left mid-sternal border. A new, painful skin lesion is shown. Which of the following is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: They are associated with infective endocarditis.

options.label: C
options.text: They are caused by immune complex deposition.

options.label: D
options.text: They can be found on the fingertips and toes.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) They are typically painless.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. They are associated with infective endocarditis : This is true. Osler's nodes are a cutaneous manifestation of infective endocarditis.
  • • Option A. They are associated with infective endocarditis
  • • Option C. They are caused by immune complex deposition: This is true. The pathogenesis of Osler's nodes involves the deposition of immune complexes in the skin, leading to inflammation and the formation of the nodules.
  • • Option C. They are caused by immune complex deposition:
  • • Option D. They can be found on the fingertips and toes: This is true. Osler's nodes are most commonly found on the pads of the fingers and toes, but they can also occur on other parts of the hands and feet.
  • • Option D. They can be found on the fingertips and toes:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Osler's nodes as a painful, cutaneous manifestation of infective endocarditis caused by immune complex deposition.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is evaluated for a 10-day history of fever and fatigue. Two years ago, he underwent dual-chamber pacemaker implantation. He reports tenderness at the site of his pacemaker, as shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma: Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma typically presents as a persistent, non-healing ulcer or nodule with a rough or scaly surface. It would not be associated with the systemic symptoms (fever, fatigue) described here, nor with tenderness at the site of a previously implanted device.
  • • Option A. Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma:
  • • Option C. Pyoderma gangrenosum : Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare inflammatory condition that typically presents with painful, rapidly progressing ulcers with a purulent base and violaceous borders. It is associated with systemic diseases like inflammatory bowel disease and rheumatoid arthritis, not with pacemaker implantation.
  • • Option C. Pyoderma gangrenosum
  • • Option D. Pyogenic granuloma : Pyogenic granuloma is a benign vascular lesion that typically appears as a small, red, rapidly growing nodule or mass, often after minor trauma. It would not typically present with systemic symptoms like fever or tenderness at a pacemaker site.
  • • Option D. Pyogenic granuloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A device-associated infection can occur after implantation of devices like pacemakers and may present with systemic symptoms such as fever, along with local signs like tenderness, erythema, and even erosion of the device through the skin.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with edema and ascites. On examination, he has elevated JVP with no respiratory variation. His BP is 110/70 mmHg and decreases to 80/60 mmHg with inspiration. 2D echo revealed a large pericardial effusion. Pericardiocentesis was performed, but intracardiac pressures remain elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Constrictive pericarditis: This would present with elevated intracardiac pressures, but there wouldn't be a significant pericardial effusion.
  • • Option A. Constrictive pericarditis:
  • • Option B. Cardiac tamponade: This would also present with elevated intracardiac pressures, but these pressures would normalize after pericardiocentesis.
  • • Option B. Cardiac tamponade:
  • • Option D. Dilated cardiomyopathy: This presents with a dilated left ventricle and reduced ejection fraction, and typically does not have elevated intracardiac pressures or pericardial effusion.
  • • Option D. Dilated cardiomyopathy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Effusive-constrictive pericarditis is a combination of pericardial effusion and constrictive pericarditis, characterized by persistently elevated intracardiac pressures even after drainage of the effusion.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with chronic kidney disease shortness of breath and diaphoresis. BP is 90/60 mm Hg and it decreases to 70/50 during inspiration. On examination, his JVP is elevated, has pitting pedal edema and heart sounds were faint. What is the next management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hemodialysis : May worsen the situation by reducing the right sided filling pressures without affecting the increased intra-pericardiac pressure in tamponade.
  • • Option A. Hemodialysis
  • • Option B. Intravenous nitroglycerin : May reduce right heart filling and may worsen hypotension.
  • • Option B. Intravenous nitroglycerin
  • • Option D. Right heart catheterization : May be useful for diagnosis but does not treat tamponade.
  • • Option D. Right heart catheterization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Definitive treatment of cardiac tamponade is pericardiocentesis or surgical pericardial drainage.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presents with edema and elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP). The JVP pressure tracing is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac tamponade: In cardiac tamponade, the x descent is typically absent or minimal, and the y descent is blunted or slow.
  • • Option A. Cardiac tamponade:
  • • Option C. Tricuspid regurgitation: This would cause a prominent v wave in the JVP tracing, not a prominent x descent.
  • • Option C. Tricuspid regurgitation:
  • • Option D. Tricuspid stenosis: Tricuspid stenosis would cause a slow y descent, but the x descent would be normal or blunted.
  • • Option D. Tricuspid stenosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Prominent x and y descent is characteristic of constrictive pericarditis. The prominent ‘y’ descent of constrictive pericarditis is also called as ‘friedrich sign’.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with acute chest pain, elevated CRP, and normal troponin levels. ECG is shown. Echocardiogram reveals a small pericardial effusion. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Echocardiographic-guided pericardiocentesis : Indicated for large effusions or tamponade, neither of which is present in this patient.
  • • Option A. Echocardiographic-guided pericardiocentesis
  • • Option B. Emergent cardiac catheterization : Not necessary as the ECG findings are not consistent with ST-elevation myocardial infarction, and troponin levels are normal.
  • • Option B. Emergent cardiac catheterization
  • • Option C. Exercise treadmill stress testing : Contraindicated in acute pericarditis due to the risk of exacerbating inflammation.
  • • Option C. Exercise treadmill stress testing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In patients with acute pericarditis, first-line treatment is high-dose aspirin or NSAIDs and adjuvant colchicine therapy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with pleuritic chest pain, fever, and malaise two weeks after a myocardial infarction (MI). On auscultation, you hear a multiphasic rub. His CRP levels are elevated, and troponin levels are slightly elevated but unchanged compared to previous values. ECG shows new ST elevations. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute pericarditis: Less likely given the recent MI.
  • • Option A. Acute pericarditis:
  • • Option C. Pulmonary embolism: Unlikely with unchanged troponin and ECG findings.
  • • Option C. Pulmonary embolism:
  • • Option D. Recurrent MI: Unlikely with unchanged troponin and ECG findings suggestive of pericarditis.
  • • Option D. Recurrent MI:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Dressler's syndrome is a post-MI pericarditis that occurs after 1-2 weeks.

questions.text: A 38-year-old homeless man presents with TIA, fever, chills, tender splenomegaly, new painful nodules on fingers, and nits on clothes. Blood cultures are negative, but echo reveals aortic valve vegetation. What test should be sent to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Epstein-Barr virus heterophile antibody: EBV does not typically cause endocarditis.
  • • Option B. Epstein-Barr virus heterophile antibody:
  • • Option C. HIV polymerase chain reaction: HIV does not cause endocarditis.
  • • Option C. HIV polymerase chain reaction:
  • • Option D. Q fever serology: While Q fever can cause culture-negative endocarditis, the patient's history and presentation are more consistent with Bartonella infection.
  • • Option D. Q fever serology:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Two most common pathogens responsible for culture negative endocarditis re

questions.text: A 19-year-old man with substance use disorder is evaluated for 3 weeks of fever and malaise and a new heart murmur. Funduscopic findings are shown. Which of the following about the finding is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: They are retinal hemorrhages with pale centers.

options.label: B
options.text: They are NOT pathognomonic for infective endocarditis.

options.label: D
options.text: They are due to septic emboli to the retina.

questions.correct_answer: D. They are due to septic emboli to the retina.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. They are retinal hemorrhages with pale centers: This is the classic description of Roth spots. The pale center is thought to represent fibrin or inflammatory cells.
  • • Option A. They are retinal hemorrhages with pale centers:
  • • Option B. They are not pathognomonic for infective endocarditis: While Roth spots are strongly associated with infective endocarditis, they can also occur in other conditions like leukemia, HIV, anemia, diabetic/hypertensive retinopathy and vasculitis.
  • • Option B. They are not pathognomonic for infective endocarditis:
  • • Option C. They are usually asymptomatic: Roth spots themselves do not usually cause any sympotms.
  • • Option C. They are usually asymptomatic:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Roth spots are examples of immunological manifestations of endocarditis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old African American male presents with nephrotic syndrome and progressive renal failure. Renal biopsy reveals focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). Which of the following genetic polymorphisms is most likely associated with his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) APOL1 polymorphism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. & B. NPHS1 and NPHS2: Mutations are associated with congenital nephrotic syndrome, not FSGS in adults.
  • • Option A. & B. NPHS1 and NPHS2:
  • • Option C. TRPC6 mutations: Can cause FSGS, but they are less common than APOL1 variants in African Americans.
  • • Option C. TRPC6 mutations:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ APOL1 gene variants are a significant risk factor for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) and other forms of non-diabetic kidney disease in individuals of African descent.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Membranous nephropathy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Minimal change disease: This is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, but less frequent in adults.
  • • Option A. Minimal change disease:
  • • Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS can cause nephrotic syndrome, but it's less common than membranous nephropathy in adults.
  • • Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS):
  • • Option D. Diabetic nephropathy: This is a leading cause of chronic kidney disease, but it typically presents with proteinuria in the absence of the full-blown nephrotic syndrome (edema, hyperlipidemia, hypoalbuminemia).
  • • Option D. Diabetic nephropathy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Membranous nephropathy is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults, especially in Caucasian populations.

questions.text: A 50-year-old obese woman with controlled hypertension has nephrotic-range proteinuria and mild edema. Renal biopsy reveals segmental scarring in 60% of glomeruli, mainly at the corticomedullary junction. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Hypertensive nephrosclerosis: While the patient has hypertension, the biopsy findings do not fit the typical pattern of nephrosclerosis (arteriolosclerosis and global glomerulosclerosis).
  • • Option B. Hypertensive nephrosclerosis:
  • • Option C. Minimal change disease: This would usually present with less severe proteinuria and no glomerular scarring on biopsy.
  • • Option C. Minimal change disease:
  • • Option D. Crescentic glomerulonephritis: This is a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis with crescents (proliferations of cells) on biopsy, not present in this case.
  • • Option D. Crescentic glomerulonephritis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is characterized by segmental scarring in a subset of glomeruli, often associated with obesity.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypokalemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Options A, B & C : These are classic features of PSGN.
  • • Options
  • • A, B & C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) typically presents with hematuria, proteinuria and hypertension, but not hypokalemia. The usual timeframe for PSGN development after impetigo is 2-6 weeks.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with hematuria and edema, three weeks after a confirmed case of impetigo. Which of the following is the most appropriate time frame for the development of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) following impetigo?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2-6 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. 1-3 weeks: This time frame is too short for PSGN to develop after a streptococcal infection like impetigo.
  • • Option A. 1-3 weeks:
  • • Option C. 3-8 weeks: While PSGN can occasionally present slightly later, the most typical window is within the first 2-6 weeks.
  • • Option C. 3-8 weeks:
  • • Option D. 2-6 days: This time frame is far too short. PSGN takes weeks, not days, to manifest.
  • • Option D. 2-6 days:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is an immune-mediated complication that can occur after a streptococcal infection. The classic presentation includes hematuria (blood in the urine), edema (swelling) and hypertension. The most common time frame for the development of PSGN following a streptococcal infection is 2-6 weeks . Recognizing this typical time frame is crucial for timely diagnosis and management of PSGN.
  • ➤ 2-6 weeks

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) presents with proteinuria, edema and a normal serum creatinine. Renal biopsy reveals Thickened basement membranes with diffuse sub-epithelial immune deposit . Which of the following complications is she at increased risk of developing?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Renal vein thrombosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute kidney injury: While possible in SLE, it's less common with class V lupus nephritis, which typically has a more insidious onset.
  • • Option A. Acute kidney injury:
  • • Option C. Nephritic syndrome: This is characterized by hematuria and hypertension, which are not prominent features of class V lupus nephritis.
  • • Option C. Nephritic syndrome:
  • • Option D. Hypocomplementemia: While common in other classes of lupus nephritis, it's not always present in class V, which is often associated with normal complement levels.
  • • Option D. Hypocomplementemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lupus nephritis class V (membranous lupus nephritis) carries an increased risk of renal vein thrombosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with hemoptysis (coughing up blood), shortness of breath and hematuria. His serum creatinine is elevated. A renal biopsy is taken and immunofluorescence is shown below. Given the likely diagnosis, what would be the immunofluorescence findings?

options.label: B
options.text: Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Mesangial cell proliferation: Is seen in IgA nephropathy and other conditions.
  • • Option A. Mesangial cell proliferation:
  • • Option C. Subepithelial immune complex deposits: Are characteristic of membranous nephropathy.
  • • Option C. Subepithelial immune complex deposits:
  • • Option D. Mesangial IgA deposits: Are seen in IgA nephropathy.
  • • Option D. Mesangial IgA deposits:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluorescence are characteristic of Goodpasture syndrome (anti-GBM disease).

questions.text: Which of the following demographic groups is MOST likely to be affected by IgA nephropathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Young men

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Elderly women: IgA nephropathy is less common in elderly individuals and slightly more common in men than women.
  • • Option A. Elderly women:
  • • Option C. Children under 5 years old: While IgA nephropathy can occur in children, it is more typically diagnosed in adolescents and young adults.
  • • Option C. Children under 5 years old:
  • • Option D. African American individuals: IgA nephropathy is less prevalent in individuals of African descent compared to those of Caucasian or Asian descent.
  • • Option D. African American individuals:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, primarily affects young men, particularly those in their teens to late 30s. While it can affect individuals of any age, gender or race, certain demographic factors increase the risk of developing this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypocomplementemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Palpable purpura: Is a common skin manifestation of AAV.
  • • Option A. Palpable purpura:
  • • Option B. Mononeuritis multiplex: (asymmetric peripheral neuropathy) is also a classic finding.
  • • Option B. Mononeuritis multiplex:
  • • Option C: Hematuria and proteinuria: Are common due to glomerulonephritis
  • • Option C: Hematuria and proteinuria:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) does not typically present with hypocomplementemia.

questions.text: What percentage of Alport syndrome cases are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 15%

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. 5%: This is the approximate percentage for the less common autosomal dominant form.
  • • Option A. 5%:
  • • Option C. 50%: This is the probability of inheritance for each child if one parent has the X-linked dominant form.
  • • Option C. 50%:
  • • Option D. 85%: This is the approximate percentage for the most common X-linked dominant form.
  • • Option D. 85%:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder primarily affecting the kidneys, hearing, and vision. While most cases (around 80-85%) are inherited in an X-linked pattern, approximately 15% of cases are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that both parents must carry a mutated gene for their child to be affected

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with recurrent hematuria and a family history of kidney disease, on further questioning he has difficulty in hearing since childhood. A renal biopsy reveals thin glomerular basement membranes (GBMs) on electron microscopy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alport syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . IgA nephropathy: Presents with mesangial IgA deposits.
  • • Option A
  • • IgA nephropathy:
  • • Option B. Thin basement membrane nephropathy ( TBMN) : This is a benign condition with persistent thin GBM, but no progression to multilamellation or other Alport features.
  • • Option B. Thin basement membrane nephropathy
  • • TBMN)
  • • Option D. Minimal change disease ( MCD): Does not cause thinning of the GBM.
  • • Option D. Minimal change disease (
  • • MCD):
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Alport syndrome is primarily inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern (approximately 85%), but 15% of cases follow an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • • Alport syndrome is primarily inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern (approximately 85%), but 15% of cases follow an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • • Thin glomerular basement membranes (GBMs) on electron microscopy, combined with recurrent hematuria and a family history of kidney disease and hearing loss, are suggestive of Alport syndrome.
  • • Thin glomerular basement membranes (GBMs) on electron microscopy, combined with recurrent hematuria and a family history of kidney disease and hearing loss, are suggestive of Alport syndrome.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with asymptomatic microscopic hematuria and a family history of similar findings. Renal function is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Alport syndrome: Usually has proteinuria and progressive kidney disease.
  • • Option A. Alport syndrome:
  • • Option B. IgA nephropathy: Presents with episodic gross hematuria, often after infections.
  • • Option B. IgA nephropathy:
  • • Option D. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN): Occurs after streptococcal infection, with edema and hypertension
  • • Option D. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Benign familial hematuria (thin basement membrane nephropathy) is the most likely diagnosis in a child with asymptomatic microscopic hematuria and a positive family history. It is a benign condition with normal renal function.

questions.text: A patient with nephrotic syndrome is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Thromboembolism: Nephrotic syndrome leads to the loss of proteins involved in blood clotting, increasing the risk of blood clots.
  • • Option A. Thromboembolism:
  • • Option B. Infection: Loss of immunoglobulins (antibodies) in the urine makes individuals more susceptible to infections.
  • • Option B. Infection:
  • • Option C. Acute kidney injury: The underlying kidney disease causing nephrotic syndrome can worsen, leading to acute kidney injury
  • • Option C. Acute kidney injury:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nephrotic syndrome increases the risk of blood clots, infections, and kidney failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a typical feature of nephrotic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Proteinuria > 3.5 g/day: This is a hallmark of nephrotic syndrome. The excessive loss of protein in the urine is a defining characteristic.
  • • Option A. Proteinuria > 3.5 g/day:
  • • Option B. Hypoalbuminemia: This occurs due to the significant loss of albumin (a protein) in the urine, leading to low albumin levels in the blood.
  • • Option B. Hypoalbuminemia:
  • • Option C. Hyperlipidemia: The liver tries to compensate for the protein loss by increasing the production of lipids (fats), leading to high levels of cholesterol and triglycerides in the blood.
  • • Option C. Hyperlipidemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by a constellation of findings, including heavy proteinuria, low albumin levels, and elevated lipids. Hyperkalemia (high potassium) is not typically associated with nephrotic syndrome; in fact, hypokalemia (low potassium) is more common due to urinary losses.
  • ➤ hypokalemia

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with generalized edema, massive proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia. Given the likely diagnosis, what would be electron microscopic findings would be present in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Thinning of the glomerular basement membrane

questions.correct_answer: D. Effacement of podocyte foot processes
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Sub-endothelial immune complex deposits: This is typically seen in lupus nephritis and other immune-complex mediated glomerulonephritis.
  • • Option A. Sub-endothelial immune complex deposits:
  • • Option B. Mesangial electron-dense deposits: This is characteristic of IgA nephropathy.
  • • Option B. Mesangial electron-dense deposits:
  • • Option C. Thinning of the glomerular basement membrane: This is seen in thin basement membrane nephropathy, a benign condition with minimal proteinuria.
  • • Option C. Thinning of the glomerular basement membrane:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical presentation strongly suggests minimal change disease (MCD) , which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. The hallmark electron microscopic finding in MCD is the effacement (flattening or fusion) of podocyte foot processes . These foot processes are crucial for the filtration barrier in the glomerulus and their damage leads to the massive proteinuria seen in nephrotic syndrome.
  • ➤ minimal change disease (MCD)
  • ➤ effacement (flattening or fusion) of podocyte foot processes

questions.text: In children diagnosed with minimal change disease (MCD), what percentage is expected to achieve spontaneous remission without specific treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 10%

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. 30%, Option C. 50% & Option D. 75%: These percentages are too high. While spontaneous remission can happen in MCD, it's not the norm. Most children require treatment with corticosteroids to achieve remission.
  • • Option B. 30%, Option C. 50% & Option D. 75%:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. The hallmark of MCD on electron microscopy is the effacement of podocyte foot processes. Spontaneous remission occurs in a minority of children with MCD (approximately 10%), while the majority respond well to corticosteroid therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese man with a history of hypertension presents with proteinuria, edema and hypoalbuminemia. Renal biopsy reveals focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). Which of the following would be the LEAST appropriate initial treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Weight loss and blood pressure control

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Options A, B & D: These are all appropriate initial interventions for secondary FSGS.
  • • Options A, B & D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Secondary FSGS, often due to obesity and hypertension, usually doesn't respond to corticosteroids. Treatment focuses on addressing the underlying cause and using renoprotective agents (ACEi/ARBs).

questions.text: A patient with obesity-related FSGS is started on a weight loss program and an ACE inhibitor. After 6 months, their proteinuria has significantly decreased. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue current therapy and monitor closely.

questions.correct_answer: A. Continue current therapy and monitor closely.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Add a corticosteroid: Corticosteroids are typically used for other forms of FSGS, not primarily obesity-related. Adding them unnecessarily could expose the patient to potential side effects without a clear benefit.
  • • Option B. Add a corticosteroid:
  • • Option C. Consider renal biopsy: A renal biopsy is typically performed at the initial diagnosis to confirm FSGS and exclude other causes. If the patient is responding well to therapy, a repeat biopsy is usually not indicated.
  • • Option C. Consider renal biopsy:
  • • Option D. Initiate dialysis: Dialysis is indicated in cases of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) when the kidneys are no longer functioning adequately. This patient is responding to therapy and does not show signs of ESRD.
  • • Option D. Initiate dialysis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If a patient with obesity-related FSGS responds well to initial therapy (weight loss and ACEi/ARB), continued monitoring is usually sufficient. Further intervention isn't immediately necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with “tram-track” appearance of renal biopsy?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. MPGN type II: Shows dense deposits within the GBM, not the tram-track appearance.
  • • Option B. MPGN type II:
  • • Option C. MPGN type III: Is similar to type I but with less prominent mesangial interposition.
  • • Option C. MPGN type III:
  • • Option D. Alport syndrome: Shows splitting and lamellation of the GBM.
  • • Option D. Alport syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "tram-track" appearance on renal biopsy is a hallmark of MPGN type I due to the characteristic mesangial interposition. This distinctive finding helps differentiate MPGN type I from other glomerular diseases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is newly diagnosed with idiopathic membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I. Which of the following statements regarding their prognosis is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: The majority of patients will experience spontaneous remission within 5 years.

options.label: B
options.text: Renal function typically remains stable for at least 20 years after diagnosis.

options.label: C
options.text: Approximately 50% of patients will develop end-stage renal disease (ESRD) within 10 years.

options.label: D
options.text: Early treatment with corticosteroids can prevent progression to ESRD in most cases.

questions.correct_answer: C. Approximately 50% of patients will develop end-stage renal disease (ESRD) within 10 years.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The majority of patients will experience spontaneous remission within 5 years : Spontaneous remission is rare in MPGN type I.
  • • Option A.
  • • The majority of patients will experience spontaneous remission within 5 years
  • • Option B. Renal function typically remains stable for at least 20 years after diagnosis: Renal function typically declines over time, with 90% of patients developing renal insufficiency within 20 years.
  • • Option B.
  • • Renal function typically remains stable for at least 20 years after diagnosis:
  • • Option D. Early treatment with corticosteroids can prevent progression to ESRD in most cases: While corticosteroids may be beneficial in some cases, they do not guarantee prevention of ESRD.
  • • Option D.
  • • Early treatment with corticosteroids can prevent progression to ESRD in most cases:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MPGN type I is a progressive disease with a poor prognosis. Approximately half of the patients progress to ESRD within 10 years, emphasizing the need for early diagnosis and management to potentially slow disease progression. While treatments like corticosteroids may be used, they do not guarantee prevention of ESRD.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the risk of urothelial malignancy in patients with analgesic nephropathy-related ESRD is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk is lower than in patients with other causes of ESRD.

options.label: B
options.text: The risk is the same as in patients with other causes of ESRD.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk is higher than in patients with other causes of ESRD.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no association between analgesic nephropathy and urothelial malignancy.

questions.correct_answer: C. The risk is higher than in patients with other causes of ESRD.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The risk is lower than in patients with other causes of ESRD: This is incorrect. The association between analgesic nephropathy and urothelial malignancy increases the risk compared to other ESRD causes.
  • • Option A. The risk is lower than in patients with other causes of ESRD:
  • • Option B. The risk is the same as in patients with other causes of ESRD: While patients with ESRD generally have a higher risk of certain malignancies, the risk of urothelial malignancy is specifically elevated in those with analgesic nephropathy.
  • • Option B. The risk is the same as in patients with other causes of ESRD:
  • • Option D. There is no association between analgesic nephropathy and urothelial malignancy: Extensive research has established a clear link between prolonged analgesic use, analgesic nephropathy, and the increased risk of developing urothelial cancers.
  • • Option D. There is no association between analgesic nephropathy and urothelial malignancy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) caused by analgesic nephropathy are at an increased risk of developing urothelial malignancies (cancers of the urinary tract) compared to individuals with ESRD from other causes.
  • ➤ increased risk

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with weight loss, heat intolerance, and palpitations. Her TSH is normal, and free T4 is elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Graves' disease: TSH would be suppressed as it is a primary hyperthyroidism. RAIU will show diffuse increase in uptake of Iodine.
  • • Option A. Graves' disease:
  • • Option B. Toxic multinodular goiter: TSH would be suppressed as it is a primary hyperthyroidism. RAIU will show patchy multi-focal increased uptake of Iodine.
  • • Option B. Toxic multinodular goiter:
  • • Option C. Subacute thyroiditis (de Quervain's thyroiditis): TSH would be suppressed as it is a primary hyperthyroidism. RAIU will show decreased uptake.
  • • Option C. Subacute thyroiditis (de Quervain's thyroiditis):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma is indicated by the combination of normal TSH and elevated free T4, consistent with central hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with congestive heart failure and sepsis. Thyroid function tests (TFT) reveal a low total T3, normal free T4 and normal TSH. What is the next step?

options.label: C
options.text: Give Levothyroxine 200µg and 100mg Hydrocortisone IV STAT

options.label: D
options.text: Observation and repeat TFT after discharge

questions.correct_answer: D. Observation and repeat TFT after discharge
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Observation and repeat TFT after discharge

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Give Levothyroxine 200µg IV STAT: Levothyroxine replacement is not indicated in SES and may even be harmful.
  • • Option A. Give Levothyroxine 200µg IV STAT:
  • • Option B. Give Hydrocortisone 100mg IV STAT: This could be appropriate for suspected adrenal insufficiency.
  • • Option B. Give Hydrocortisone 100mg IV STAT:
  • • Option C. Give Levothyroxine 200µg and 100mg Hydrocortisone IV STAT: This could be an appropriate treatment for myxedema coma.
  • • Option C. Give Levothyroxine 200µg and 100mg Hydrocortisone IV STAT:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with sick euthyroid syndrome, characterized by low total T3, normal free T4, and normal TSH in the context of critical illness, observation and repeat TFTs after recovery is the appropriate management.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with growth retardation, delayed bone age, and normal intellect. His thyroid function tests reveal elevated T3, T4, and normal TSH levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Refetoff syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma: This would result in elevated TSH and T4 levels, but the patient would likely exhibit symptoms of hyperthyroidism.
  • • Option B. TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma:
  • • Option C. McCune-Albright syndrome: This syndrome is associated with precocious puberty, bone lesions, and café-au-lait spots.
  • • Option C. McCune-Albright syndrome:
  • • Option D. Graves' disease: This autoimmune disorder causes clinical hyperthyroidism with elevated T4 and suppressed TSH levels.
  • • Option D. Graves' disease:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Refetoff syndrome, or resistance to thyroid hormone (RTH), presents with elevated T3 and T4, normal TSH levels, growth retardation, and delayed bone age, with the patient usually being clinically euthyroid or hypothyroid.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of palpitations and excessive sweating. Physical examination reveals a non-tender thyroid gland. Thyroid function tests show an elevated free T4 and suppressed TSH. Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scan is shown. Thyroglobulin levels are low. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thyrotoxicosis factitia.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Graves' disease: Graves' disease is an autoimmune condition causing hyperthyroidism. It typically presents with a diffuse goiter, increased RAIU, and high thyroglobulin levels.
  • • Option A. Graves' disease:
  • • Option C. Toxic Multinodular Goiter: This condition also has an increased RAIU and increased thyroglobulin levels.
  • • Option C. Toxic Multinodular Goiter:
  • • Option D. Thyroiditis: RAIU can be suppressed but thyroglobulin levels are usually elevated in thyroiditis.
  • • Option D. Thyroiditis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thyrotoxicosis factitia is characterized by low radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) and low thyroglobulin levels, indicating exogenous thyroid hormone use.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of fatigue and constipation. Thyroid function tests show reduced free T4 and increased TSH levels. Which of the following symptoms or signs is LEAST likely to be associated with her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cardiac tamponade

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Alopecia: Hypothyroidism can cause hair loss due to slowed metabolism and decreased hair growth.
  • • Option A. Alopecia:
  • • Option B. Amenorrhea: Hypothyroidism can disrupt menstrual cycles (Menorrhagia initially and oligo/amenorrhea in long standing disease).
  • • Option B. Amenorrhea:
  • • Option C. Carpal tunnel syndrome: Hypothyroidism can cause fluid retention and swelling, which can compress the median nerve in the wrist, leading to carpal tunnel syndrome
  • • Option C. Carpal tunnel syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiac tamponade is the least likely symptom associated with primary hypothyroidism, despite pericardial effusion being relatively common.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding congenital hypothyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: Thyroid dyshormonogenesis is the most common cause.

options.label: B
options.text: Most infants appear normal at birth.

options.label: C
options.text: The recommended initial dose of levothyroxine is 10-15 µg/kg/day.

options.label: D
options.text: Early treatment can significantly improve neurodevelopmental outcomes.

questions.correct_answer: A. Thyroid dyshormonogenesis is the most common cause.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thyroid dyshormonogenesis is the most common cause.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Most infants appear normal at birth: The majority of infants appear normal at birth (but classic features are prolonged jaundice, poor feeding, hypotonia, macroglossia, delayed bone maturation, and umbilical hernia).
  • • Option B. Most infants appear normal at birth:
  • • Option C. The recommended initial dose of levothyroxine is 10-15 µg/kg/day: When the diagnosis is confirmed, T4 is instituted at a dose of 10–15 μg/kg/day and the dose is adjusted by close monitoring of TSH levels.
  • • Option C. The recommended initial dose of levothyroxine is 10-15 µg/kg/day:
  • • Option D. Early treatment can significantly improve neurodevelopmental outcomes: Early treatment with T4 results in normal IQ levels, but subtle neurodevelopmental abnormalities may occur in those with the most severe hypothyroidism at diagnosis or when treatment is delayed or suboptimal.
  • • Option D. Early treatment can significantly improve neurodevelopmental outcomes:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thyroid gland dysgenesis, not thyroid dyshormonogenesis, is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old hypothyroid patient calls your OPD and informs that she has missed her thyroxine tablet the previous day and asks what to do about it. What will be your advice?

options.label: A
options.text: Ask her to review immediately to the hospital

options.label: B
options.text: Ask her to take 2 tablets today

options.label: C
options.text: Skip the missed dose and resume from today

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: B. Ask her to take 2 tablets today

Ans. B) Ask her to take 2 tablets today

Explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Advise hypothyroid patients who miss a dose of thyroxine to take two doses the next day due to the long half-life of T4.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A-iv, B-iii, C-ii, D-i

Explanation:

For adults with indications to treat in a subclinical hypothyroidism treatment is administered by starting with a low dose of LT4 (25–50 μg/d). In the elderly, especially patients with known coronary artery disease, the starting dose of LT4 is 12.5–25 μg/d.
