questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis is brought to the emergency department with altered mental status, hypothermia (35°C), bradycardia (45 bpm), and hypotension (80/50 mmHg). Her skin is dry and doughy, and she has non-pitting edema in her extremities. Which of the following is the NOT indicated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) External Rewarming

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Levothyroxine 200 μg IV bolus: LT4 single IV bolus of 200–400 μg (loading dose) is the preferred initial treatment in myxedema coma (alternate if no IV avaialble: NG tube LT4).
  • • Option A.
  • • Levothyroxine 200
  • • μg IV bolus:
  • • Option B. IV Hydrocortisone 50mg 6 th hourly: Parenteral hydrocortisone (50 mg every 6 h) should be administered because there is impaired adrenal reserve in profound hypothyroidism
  • • Option B. IV Hydrocortisone 50mg 6 th hourly:
  • • Option C. IV broad spectrum Antibiotics: Sepsis is an important precipitating cause of myxedema coma. Early use of broad-spectrum antibiotics is warranted until infection is excluded.
  • • Option C. IV broad spectrum Antibiotics:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ External (active) rewarming is not indicated for myxedema coma unless the temperature is below 30°C, as it can result in cardiovascular collapse.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of Graves' disease presents to the emergency department with fever, tachycardia, agitation, and vomiting. She recently underwent a dental procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for her suspected condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Propylthiouracil (PTU)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Propranolol (A): Can be used for cardio-protection but not immediately required.
  • • Option A. Propranolol (A):
  • • Option C. Radioactive iodine (C) : Not suitable for acute management of thyrotoxic crisis.
  • • Option C. Radioactive iodine (C)
  • • Option D. Hydrocortisone (D) : Adjunctive therapy in thyroid storm, can be added later.
  • • Option D. Hydrocortisone (D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the most appropriate initial treatment for thyrotoxic crisis (thyroid storm) due to its rapid onset of action and ability to inhibit peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

questions.text: All of the following are features of thyrotoxicosis except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypocalciuria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Sinus Tachycardia: The most common CV manifestation in thyrotoxicosis is sinus tachycardia. Atrial fibrillation is more common in patients >50 years of age.
  • • Option A. Sinus Tachycardia:
  • • Option B. Polyuria : Probably due to increased renal blood flow and hypercalciuria.
  • • Option B. Polyuria
  • • Option C. Hypercalcemia: This is due to the effect of thyroid hormones causing bone resorption.
  • • Option C. Hypercalcemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypercalciuria, not hypocalciuria, is a common feature of thyrotoxicosis due to the effect of thyroid hormones on bone resorption.

questions.text: A patient with thyrotoxicosis develops atrial fibrillation. Which of the following statements regarding their management is CORRECT?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Long-term anticoagulation is unnecessary

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Age < 50 is a risk factor: Elderly patients (Age >50) are at increased risk.
  • • Option A. Age < 50 is a risk factor:
  • • Option C. Digoxin sensitivity is increased: Digoxin sensitivity is decreased because of increased renal clearance and increased number of Na-K ATPse.
  • • Option C. Digoxin sensitivity is increased:
  • • Option D. Warfarin sensitivity is decreased: Warfarin sensitivity is increased as production of vitamin K dependent clotting factors are reduced.
  • • Option D. Warfarin sensitivity is decreased:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Long-term anticoagulation is generally unnecessary in patients with atrial fibrillation and thyrotoxicosis, as spontaneous reversion to sinus rhythm often occurs with control of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male smoker with a history of Graves' disease presents with weight loss and loss of appetite. He is on carbimazole 5mg per day, and his recent free T4 levels (done a week ago) were normal. He has mild orbitopathy but no dermopathy. On examination, you notice clubbing; otherwise, he is vitally stable. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CT of the chest

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. MRI of the orbit: It not the primary concern given the new symptoms and clubbing.
  • • Option A. MRI of the orbit:
  • • Option B. X-ray of hands with wrist: May be useful in thyroid acropachy (It refers to a form of clubbing found in < 1% of patients with Graves’ disease. It is so strongly associated with thyroid dermopathy that an alternative cause of clubbing should be sought in a Graves’ patient without coincident skin and orbital involvement).
  • • Option B. X-ray of hands with wrist:
  • • Option D. Repeat TFT: Repeating thyroid function tests is unlikely to yield new information.
  • • Option D. Repeat TFT:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a smoker with Graves' disease presenting with clubbing, weight loss, and loss of appetite, a CT of the chest is indicated to rule out an underlying lung malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided in children with Graves disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Propylthiouracil

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Methimazole: Preferred treatment in children with Graves disease.
  • • Option B. Methimazole:
  • • Option C. Radioactive Iodine Ablation: Usually reserved for refractory/severe Graves disease in children.
  • • Option C. Radioactive Iodine Ablation:
  • • Option D. Thyroidectomy: Usually reserved for refractory/severe Graves disease in children.
  • • Option D. Thyroidectomy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Propylthiouracil should be avoided in children with Graves' disease due to the risk of hepatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely in a case of neonatal thyrotoxicosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reduced Bone Age

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Poor intrauterine growth: Common feature due to increased basal metabolic rate in the fetus with thyrotoxicosis.
  • • Option A. Poor intrauterine growth:
  • • Option C. Fetal tachycardia: HR > 160/min is commin in the fetus with thyrotoxicosis.
  • • Option C. Fetal tachycardia:
  • • Option D. Fetal goiter: Common due to trophic effects of antibodies on the thyroid gland.
  • • Option D. Fetal goiter:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neonatal thyrotoxicosis is associated with advanced bone age, not reduced bone age.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with Graves' disease undergoes RAI therapy. Two months later, she complains of persistent palpitations and heat intolerance. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her persistent symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: RAI therapy is ineffective in young patients.

options.label: B
options.text: The patient is experiencing a relapse of Graves' disease.

options.label: D
options.text: The full effect of RAI therapy takes 2-3 months to manifest.

questions.correct_answer: D. The full effect of RAI therapy takes 2-3 months to manifest.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The full effect of RAI therapy takes 2-3 months to manifest.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . RAI therapy is ineffective in young patients: RAI is effective in all age groups.
  • • Option A
  • • RAI therapy is ineffective in young patients:
  • • Option B . The patient is experiencing a relapse of Graves' disease: Relapse is possible, but less likely within two months.
  • • Option B
  • • The patient is experiencing a relapse of Graves' disease:
  • • Option C . The patient is developing hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is a later complication of RAI.
  • • Option C
  • • The patient is developing hypothyroidism:
  • • Summary of RAIA in Graves:
  • • Summary of RAIA in Graves:
  • • Indication : Initial treatment or for relapses after antithyroid drugs. Tracer used: I131. Emits β & γ. t1/2 ∼ 8 days. Elderly/Cardiac Patients: Consider pretreatment with antithyroid drugs and beta-blockers (because of small, increased risk of Thyrotoxic Crisis) Carbimazole/Methimazole: Stop 2-3 days before and restart 3-7 days after RAI. PTU: Prolonged radioprotective effect, requires longer discontinuation or higher RAI dose. Persistence of Hyperthyroidism: Can persist for 2-3 months, managed with beta-blockers or antithyroid drugs. Safety Precautions: Avoid close contact with children and pregnant women for 5-7 days. Complications: Radiation Thyroiditis: Mild pain may occur 1-2 weeks after treatment. Flare of Orbitopathy: Especially in smokers. Consider prednisone pre-treatment. Permanent Hypothyroidism: Risk is 10-20% in the first year, 5% per year thereafter, requiring lifelong LT4 replacement. Possibly a small increased lifetime risk of solid cancers. Contraindications: Pregnancy, breastfeeding and suspected thyroid cancer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with progressive confusion, memory loss, and seizures. She also has a history of hypothyroidism and she is on Levothyroxine 75 µg/d. Her records suggest a high anti TPO antibodies and MRI of the brain reveals diffuse white matter hyperintensities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hashimoto's encephalopathy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Multiple sclerosis (MS): MS follows dissemination in space and time and it is not associated with anti TPO antibodies.
  • • Option A. Multiple sclerosis (MS):
  • • Option B. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML): It is caused by JC virus and is usually seen in immunocompromised individuals.
  • • Option B. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML):
  • • Option D. Neurosarcoidosis: The clinical features are NOT compatible with the diagnosis.
  • • Option D. Neurosarcoidosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hashimoto's encephalopathy, also known as steroid-responsive encephalopathy associated with autoimmune thyroiditis (SREAT), is characterized by progressive confusion, memory loss, seizures, high anti-TPO antibodies, and diffuse white matter hyperintensities on MRI.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Hashimoto’s thyroiditis?

options.label: A
options.text: TPO and Tg antibodies in the mother can cause fetal hypothyroidism.

options.label: B
options.text: High Iodine intake increases the risk.

options.label: C
options.text: Thyroid destruction is primarily mediated by the CD8+ cytotoxic T cells.

questions.correct_answer: A. TPO and Tg antibodies in the mother can cause fetal hypothyroidism.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TPO and Tg antibodies in the mother can cause fetal hypothyroidism.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. High Iodine intake increases the risk: A high iodine or low selenium intake and decreased exposure to microorganisms in childhood increases risk.
  • • Option B. High Iodine intake increases the risk:
  • • Option C. Thyroid destruction is primarily mediated by the CD8+ cytotoxic T cells: True. Pathogenic effect of antibodies is restricted to a secondary role in amplifying an ongoing autoimmune response.
  • • Option C. Thyroid destruction is primarily mediated by the CD8+ cytotoxic T cells:
  • • Option D. Alcohol intake is protective: Smoking cessation transiently increases incidence, whereas alcohol intake seems protective.
  • • Option D. Alcohol intake is protective:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transplacental passage of Tg or TPO antibodies has no effect on the fetal thyroid, whereas TSH-R blocking antibodies may induce transient neonatal hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with severe fatigue. Thyroid function tests reveal low free T4, high TSH, and elevated anti-TPO antibodies. Which of the following statements regarding the histopathological findings in her thyroid gland is FALSE?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Absence of fibrosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Lymphocytic infiltration: Hallmark of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis and can form germinal centres within the gland.
  • • Option A. Lymphocytic infiltration:
  • • Option B. Atrophy of thyroid follicles: The destruction of thyroid follicles by the immune system leads to their shrinkage and atrophy.
  • • Option B. Atrophy of thyroid follicles:
  • • Option D. Goiter: In the early stages of Hashimoto's, the thyroid gland may become enlarged (goiter) due to inflammation. However, as the disease progresses, the gland can shrink due to atrophy. Atrophy is especially common in Asians.
  • • Option D. Goiter:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hashimoto's thyroiditis histopathology includes lymphocytic infiltration, atrophy of thyroid follicles, and fibrosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a one-week history of fever, neck pain, and fatigue. On physical examination, her thyroid gland is tender. Thyroid function tests reveal elevated free T4 and suppressed TSH. Which of the following statements regarding her underlying condition is FALSE?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Positive anti-TPO.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Associated with URI: This is a true statement, as De Quervain’s thyroiditis is often triggered by a viral infection.
  • • Option
  • • A. Associated with URI:
  • • Option B. Elevated ESR: This is also true due to the inflammatory process.
  • • Option B. Elevated ESR:
  • • Option D. Giant cells in biopsy: This is the characteristic histological finding due to the presence of granulomas in De Quervain’s thyroiditis.
  • • Option D. Giant cells in biopsy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies are usually negative in subacute (De Quervain’s) thyroiditis, which is associated with an elevated ESR and giant cells in biopsy following an upper respiratory infection.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician 6 months after delivery with complaints of fatigue, cold intolerance, and weight gain for the last 3 weeks. She also reports feeling depressed and having difficulty concentrating. Her thyroid function tests reveal elevated TSH and low free T4 levels and positive anti-TPO antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. De Quervain's thyroiditis: This is a painful form of thyroiditis and they have an elevated ESR. Anti TPO antibodies are rarely positive in De Quervain’s.
  • • Option A. De Quervain's thyroiditis:
  • • Option C. Riedel's thyroiditis: This is a rare fibrotic thyroiditis with a hard, fixed goiter.
  • • Option C. Riedel's thyroiditis:
  • • Option D. Hashimoto's thyroiditis: While also autoimmune, Hashimoto's typically presents with a gradual (chronic) onset of hypothyroidism and is less likely to occur postpartum.
  • • Option D. Hashimoto's thyroiditis:
  • • Summary of post-partum thyroiditis:
  • • Summary of post-partum thyroiditis:
  • • Similar to De Quervain’s thyroiditis, but painless and have normal ESR. Occurs in 5% of women 3-6 months postpartum, termed postpartum thyroiditis. Associated with TPO antibodies antepartum, 3x more common in type 1 diabetes. Recovery is the rule. Annual follow-up recommended as some develop permanent hypothyroidism. May recur in subsequent pregnancies.
  • • Similar to De Quervain’s thyroiditis, but painless and have normal ESR.
  • • Occurs in 5% of women 3-6 months postpartum, termed postpartum thyroiditis.
  • • Associated with TPO antibodies antepartum, 3x more common in type 1 diabetes.
  • • Recovery is the rule. Annual follow-up recommended as some develop permanent hypothyroidism. May recur in subsequent pregnancies.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis, also known as painless thyroiditis, often presents postpartum with a hypothyroid phase and positive anti-TPO antibodies.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a firm, non-tender, fixed goiter and complaints of difficulty swallowing and hoarseness. Fine needle aspiration is inconclusive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Perform open biopsy for definitive diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Perform open biopsy for definitive diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Perform open biopsy for definitive diagnosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Start treatment with levothyroxine: Levothyroxine is used to treat hypothyroidism, which is uncommon (TFT is often normal) in Riedel's thyroiditis.
  • • Option A. Start treatment with levothyroxine:
  • • Option B. Initiate radioactive iodine therapy: Radioactive iodine therapy is used to treat hyperthyroidism, not indicated in this case.
  • • Option B. Initiate radioactive iodine therapy:
  • • Option D. Begin glucocorticoid therapy: Glucocorticoids may be considered after a definitive diagnosis of Riedel's thyroiditis is established, but not as the initial step.
  • • Option D. Begin glucocorticoid therapy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perform an open biopsy for a definitive diagnosis in a patient with a firm, non-tender, fixed goiter and compressive symptoms, as this presentation is highly suggestive of Riedel's thyroiditis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation treated with amiodarone presents with weight loss, palpitations, and heat intolerance. Thyroid function tests reveal suppressed TSH and elevated free T4. Thyroid USG shows decreased vascularity. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucocorticoids (prednisone)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Potassium perchlorate: Used in type 1 AIT (increases synthesis, increased vascularity).
  • • Option A. Potassium perchlorate:
  • • Option B. High-dose antithyroid drugs: Also used in type 1 AIT, ineffective in type 2 due to the release of preformed hormone.
  • • Option B. High-dose antithyroid drugs:
  • • Option D. Thyroidectomy: Reserved for severe, unresponsive cases, not the initial approach.
  • • Option D. Thyroidectomy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucocorticoids (prednisone) are the first-line treatment for amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis (AIT) type 2, characterized by destructive thyroiditis and decreased vascularity on ultrasound.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a palpable thyroid nodule and has normal TSH levels. USG reveals a hypoechoic solid nodule with microcalcifications. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Observation and repeat USG in 6 months

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNA)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Observation and repeat USG in 6 months: This approach is suitable for smaller or less suspicious nodules but not for those with high-risk features like microcalcifications. Delayed diagnosis could lead to potential complications if the nodule is malignant.
  • • Option A. Observation and repeat USG in 6 months:
  • • Option C. Radioiodine scanning: Useful only if hyperthyroid on TFTs.
  • • Option C. Radioiodine scanning:
  • • Option D. Thyroid lobectomy: Surgery is usually reserved for confirmed malignancy or large symptomatic nodules. FNA is required for diagnosis before considering surgery.
  • • Option D. Thyroid lobectomy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papillary thyroid cancer generally has a good prognosis, and its presence is not associated with a poor prognosis compared to other types of thyroid cancer.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with a rapidly enlarging neck mass and hoarseness. Fine needle aspiration biopsy reveals thyroid cancer. Which of the following factors is NOT associated with a poor prognosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Papillary histology

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Male gender: Male gender is associated with a worse prognosis in thyroid cancer compared to female gender.
  • • Option A. Male gender:
  • • Option B. Age > 65 years: Older age at diagnosis is a significant risk factor for poorer outcomes in thyroid cancer.
  • • Option B. Age > 65 years:
  • • Option D. p53 mutations: p53 mutations are associated with a more aggressive tumor behavior and a poorer prognosis in thyroid cancer.
  • • Option D. p53 mutations:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papillary histology in thyroid cancer is not associated with a poor prognosis and generally indicates a good outcome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is diagnosed with papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC). Which of the following statements is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: BRAF mutation is the most common genetic alteration

options.label: B
options.text: Lymph node micrometastases indicates poor prognosis.

options.label: C
options.text: It has a propensity to spread via the lymphatic system.

options.label: D
options.text: PTC is present in up to 25% of thyroid glands at autopsy

questions.correct_answer: B. Lymph node micrometastases indicates poor prognosis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lymph node micrometastases indicates poor prognosis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. BRAF mutation is the most common genetic alteration: True. a. BRAF V600E mutations reduce uptake of RAI and increase risk of recurrence (but effect on overall outcomes in unclear).
  • • Option A. BRAF mutation is the most common genetic alteration:
  • • Option C. It has a propensity to spread via the lymphatic system: This is true. PTC has a tendency to spread to the lymph nodes in the neck.
  • • Option C. It has a propensity to spread via the lymphatic system:
  • • Option D. PTC is present in up to 25% of thyroid glands at autopsy: This is also true. Many people have small, microscopic PTCs that never cause any problems.
  • • Option D. PTC is present in up to 25% of thyroid glands at autopsy:
  • • Summary if important thyroid cancers:
  • • Summary if important thyroid cancers:
  • • PTC: Most common type of thyroid cancer (80-85% of differentiated thyroid cancers) Genetics: RET/PTC rearrangements (20-40%), BRAF V600E mutation (most common), RAS mutations (20-30%).
  • • PTC: Most common type of thyroid cancer (80-85% of differentiated thyroid cancers) Genetics: RET/PTC rearrangements (20-40%), BRAF V600E mutation (most common), RAS mutations (20-30%).
  • • PTC:

  • • Genetics: RET/PTC rearrangements (20-40%), BRAF V600E mutation (most common), RAS mutations (20-30%).
  • • BRAF V600E mutations reduce uptake of RAI and increase risk of recurrence (but effect on overall outcomes in unclear).
  • • BRAF V600E mutations reduce uptake of RAI and increase risk of recurrence (but effect on overall outcomes in unclear).
  • • Microscopic PTC is found in ∼ 25% of autopsy thyroids (clinically insignificant). Characteristic cytological features: Orphan Annie eye appearance with Nuclear grooves and Prominent nucleoli. Tall cell, columnar cell, hobnail, poorly differentiated – aggressive variants. Can be multifocal & invade locally within the thyroid gland/ adjacent structures. Usually Spreads primarily via lymphatic system. Slow growth can lead to a significant burden of pulmonary metastases with few symptoms. Lymph node involvement is prognostic but micro metastases (< 2 mm) does not alter prognosis. Most PTCs are identified in early stages (I or II) with excellent prognosis. Stage IV disease has markedly increased mortality but is rare (~1%).

  • • Diagnosis: Difficult by FNA alone, requires Bx to assess capsular/vascular invasion.
  • • Prognosis:
  • • Capsular invasion only: Low risk of metastasis, lobectomy suffices. Angioinvasive FTC: More aggressive, can metastasize to bone, lung, and CNS.
  • • Capsular invasion only: Low risk of metastasis, lobectomy suffices.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding thyroid cancer treatment after thyroidectomy?

options.label: A
options.text: S. Tg is a sensitive marker post-surgery.

options.label: B
options.text: Universal Target TSH post-surgery is 0.5-2 mIU/L.

options.label: C
options.text: Patient should follow low Iodine diet for 1-2 weeks prior to I131 therapy.

options.label: D
options.text: TSH > 25 is required at the time of I 131 therapy.

questions.correct_answer: B. Universal Target TSH post-surgery is 0.5-2 mIU/L.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Universal Target TSH post-surgery is 0.5-2 mIU/L.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. S. Tg is a sensitive marker post-surgery: This is true. Serum thyroglobulin (Tg) is a useful tumor marker for monitoring patients with papillary and follicular thyroid cancers after thyroidectomy.
  • • Option A. S. Tg is a sensitive marker post-surgery:
  • • Option C. Patient should follow low Iodine diet for 1-2 weeks prior to I131 therapy: This is also true. A low iodine diet is recommended before radioactive iodine (RAI) therapy to enhance the uptake of iodine by any remaining thyroid tissue or cancer cells.
  • • Option C. Patient should follow low Iodine diet for 1-2 weeks prior to I131 therapy:
  • • Option D. TSH > 25 is required at the time of I131 therapy: This is generally true for patients with high-risk thyroid cancer. A higher TSH level helps stimulate the uptake of RAI by thyroid cancer cells.
  • • Option D. TSH > 25 is required at the time of I131 therapy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The target TSH level post-surgery for thyroid cancer patients is based on the risk of recurrence, not universally 0.5-2 mIU/L. It ranges from 0.5-2.0 mIU/L for low risk, 0.1-0.5 mIU/L for intermediate risk, to <0.1 mIU/L for high risk or metastatic disease.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease presents with muscle cramps and tingling in her fingers. Her serum calcium is 7.7 mg/dL (normal: 8.5-10.5 mg/dL) and serum albumin is 3.0 g/dL (normal range: 3.5-5.0 g/dL). What is her corrected calcium level?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 8.5 mg/dL

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Corrected calcium is calculated using the following formula:
  • • Corrected calcium (mg/dL) = Measured calcium (mg/dL) + 0.8 x (4.0 - Albumin [g/dL])
  • • In this case:
  • • Corrected calcium = 7.5 + 0.8 x (4.0 - 3.0) = 7.7 + 0.8 = 8.5 mg/dL
  • • Therefore, the patient's corrected calcium level is 8.5 mg/dL, which is within the normal range.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To calculate the corrected calcium level in patients with low serum albumin, use the formula:
  • ➤ Corrected calcium (mg/dL) = Measured calcium (mg/dL) + 0.8 x (4.0 - Albumin [g/dL])

questions.text: Which of the following regarding calcium homeostasis is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced S. Ig levels can increase total serum calcium levels.

options.label: B
options.text: DCT is the major site for active calcium reabsorption in the kidney.

options.label: C
options.text: CaSR in the cortical TAL in the kidney works independent of Vit D and PTH.

options.label: D
options.text: Passive intestinal absorption is non saturable.

questions.correct_answer: A. Reduced S. Ig levels can increase total serum calcium levels.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reduced S. Ig levels can increase total serum calcium levels.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . DCT is the major site for active calcium reabsorption in the kidney: True. Via TRPV5.
  • • Option B
  • • DCT is the major site for active calcium reabsorption in the kidney:
  • • Option C . CaSR in the cortical TAL in the kidney works independent of Vit D and PTH: CaSR senses only Ca and Mg . PTH or Vit D does NOT exert control on CaSR.
  • • Option C
  • • CaSR in the cortical TAL in the kidney works independent of Vit D and
  • • PTH:
  • • Option D . Passive intestinal absorption is non saturable: True. Main reason for hypercalcemia with large intakes of calcium (e.g., Milk Alkali Syndrome).
  • • Option D
  • • Passive intestinal absorption is non saturable:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alterations in serum protein concentrations, such as albumin and immunoglobulin (Ig) levels, directly affect the total serum calcium concentration but do not change the ionized calcium levels. Corrected calcium should be calculated in relation to albumin and Ig concentrations.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding Phosphorus homeostasis is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Majority of phosphorus absorption in intestine is Vitamin D dependent.

options.label: B
options.text: Serum levels are best measured in fasting state.

options.label: C
options.text: PTH and FGF23 increase Na-Pi transporter activity in the PCT.

options.label: D
options.text: Concentration of phosphorus is more in ECF compared to ICF.

questions.correct_answer: B. Serum levels are best measured in fasting state.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Serum levels are best measured in fasting state.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Majority of phosphorus absorption in intestine is Vitamin D dependent: Phosphorus is absorbed efficiently (65%) even without vitamin D. Vit D increases absorption to 85-90%.
  • • Option A. Majority of phosphorus absorption in intestine is Vitamin D dependent:
  • • Option C. PTH and FGF23 increase Na-Pi transporter activity in the PCT: PTH and FGF23 reduce Na-Pi levels, increasing phosphate excretion.
  • • Option C. PTH and FGF23 increase Na-Pi transporter activity in the PCT:
  • • Option D. Concentration of phosphorus is more in ICF compared to ECF: Phosphorus is the most abundant intracellular anion. ECF concentrations and amount are generally lower.
  • • Option D. Concentration of phosphorus is more in ICF compared to ECF:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serum phosphorus levels are best measured in the fasting state due to variations caused by food intake and circadian rhythms.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with chronic alcoholism was started in IV dextrose. He develops cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, and rhabdomyolysis. Which of the following electrolyte disturbances is most likely responsible for her clinical deterioration?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypophosphatemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hypernatremia: Hypernatremia (high sodium) is not a typical feature of refeeding syndrome.
  • • Option A. Hypernatremia:
  • • Option B. Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia (low calcium) can occur in refeeding syndrome, but it is less common and less severe than hypophosphatemia.
  • • Option B. Hypocalcemia:
  • • Option C. Hyperphosphatemia: Hyperphosphatemia (high phosphate) is the opposite of what is seen in refeeding syndrome.
  • • Option C. Hyperphosphatemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Refeeding syndrome, commonly occurring in severely malnourished individuals after reintroducing nutrition, is characterized by hypophosphatemia, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, seizures, and rhabdomyolysis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old chronic alcoholic developed refeeding syndrome and is about to get IV phosphate replacement. Which of the following is true?

options.label: B
options.text: Hypocalcemia, if present must be corrected first.

options.label: C
options.text: Increase dose of phosphate if hypercalcemic.

questions.correct_answer: B. Hypocalcemia, if present must be corrected first.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypocalcemia, if present must be corrected first

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Phosphate cannot be administered IV: Phosphate can be administered IV, usually as sodium or potassium phosphate salts. Less severe hypophosphatemia (1.5–2.5 mg/dL) can be treated with oral phosphate (750–2000 mg/d as elemental phosphorus) but higher doses can cause bloating and diarrhea.
  • • Option A. Phosphate cannot be administered IV:
  • • Option C. Increase the dose of phosphate if hypercalcemic: Reduce dose of phosphate by 50% if the patient is hypercalcemic (serum Ca-PO4 product must be <50 mg2/dL2 to reduce the risk of heterotopic calcification).
  • • Option C. Increase the dose of phosphate if hypercalcemic:
  • • Reduction of dose is also recommended in patients with renal dysfunction.
  • • Option D. Hyperglycemia is common: Hypoglycemia is common due to increased glucose entry and utilization by tissues. Hence concurrent dextrose administration can be considered (especially in those at risk of hypoglycemia).
  • • Option D. Hyperglycemia is common:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In refeeding syndrome, hypocalcemia, if present, must be corrected before administering IV phosphate to prevent further hypocalcemia.

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibodies has been approved for X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Burosumab

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Teplizumab: This monoclonal antibody (CD3) is used in the treatment of type 1 diabetes.
  • • Option B. Teplizumab:
  • • Option C. Teprotumumab: This monoclonal antibody (IGF-1r) is used in the treatment of thyroid eye disease (Graves' ophthalmopathy).
  • • Option C. Teprotumumab:
  • • Option D. Atezolizumab: This monoclonal antibody (PD-L1) is used in the treatment of certain types of cancer.
  • • Option D. Atezolizumab:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Burosumab is a monoclonal antibody approved for X-linked hypophosphatemia (XLH).

questions.text: Which of the following regarding Magnesium (Mg) homeostasis is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Mg is primarily absorbed in the jejunum.

options.label: B
options.text: Vitamin D can increase Mg absorption.

options.label: C
options.text: Majority of Mg is reabsorbed in the PCT.

options.label: D
options.text: Mg reabsorption is inhibited by hypercalcemia.

questions.correct_answer: C. Majority of Mg is reabsorbed in the PCT.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Majority of Mg is reabsorbed in the PCT.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Mg is primarily absorbed in the jejunum: This is true, although some absorption also occurs in the ileum. Usual absorption is 30-40% but can increase to 70% during deficiency states.
  • • Option A. Mg is primarily absorbed in the jejunum:
  • • Option B. Vitamin D can increase Mg absorption: This is true, although the mechanism is not fully understood.
  • • Option B. Vitamin D can increase Mg absorption:
  • • Option D. Mg reabsorption is inhibited by hypercalcemia: This is also true. Magnesium reabsorption in the cTAL is increased by PTH but inhibited by hypercalcemia or hypermagnesemia, both of which activate the CaSR in this nephron segment.
  • • Option D. Mg reabsorption is inhibited by hypercalcemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The majority of magnesium is reabsorbed in the cortical thick ascending limb (cTAL) of the kidney.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man who is a known case of Gitelman’s syndrome presents with tetany. On evaluation his serum Mg level is 0.6 g/dL (normal: 1.7-2.4 mg/dL). Which of the following is true?

options.label: C
options.text: IM MgSO4 is as effective as IV MgSO4.

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin D deficiency, if present should be corrected with calcitriol.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Co-existent hypocalcemia is common.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Protective against Digitalis toxicity: Hypomagnesemia actually increases the risk of digitalis toxicity (ECG abnormalities in hypomagnesemia: Prolonged PR or QT intervals, T-wave flattening or inversion, and ST straightening).
  • • Option A. Protective against Digitalis toxicity:
  • • Option C. IM MgSO4 is as effective as IV MgSO4: For IV use, MgCl2 is generally preferred. IV MgSO4 is inferior because sulfate anions may bind calcium in serum and urine and aggravate hypocalcemia.
  • • Option C. IM MgSO4 is as effective as IV MgSO4:
  • • Use of IM MgSO4 is discouraged - the injections are painful and provide relatively little magnesium (2 mL of 50% MgSO4 supplies only 4 mmol).
  • • Option D. Vitamin D deficiency, if present, should be corrected with calcitriol: Vitamin D deficiency frequently coexists with hypomagnesemia and should be treated with calcidiol (but not with calcitriol, which may impair tubular magnesium reabsorption, possibly via PTH suppression by acting on VDR in the parathyroid gland).
  • • Option D. Vitamin D deficiency, if present, should be corrected with calcitriol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Co-existent hypocalcemia is common in patients with severe hypomagnesemia, such as in Gitelman's syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue and bone pain. Laboratory findings reveal low serum calcium, elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH), and low 25-hydroxyvitamin D [calcidiol] levels. Which of the following statements regarding this patient's condition is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: Expansion of the proliferating zone is seen in rickets.

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: B. Expansion of the proliferating zone is seen in rickets.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Expansion of the proliferating zone is seen in rickets.

Explanation:

Looser's zones seen in osteomalacia occur near large arteries: These radiolucent lines, also known as pseudofractures, are characteristic of osteomalacia and are often found adjacent to large arteries. These are often long, but only a few mm wide and common in scapula, pelvis and femoral neck.
  • • Option C. Looser's zones seen in osteomalacia occur near large arteries:

If 1α-hydroxylation is defective, use metabolites not requiring activation (calcitriol, doxercalciferol, alfacalcidol). Monitor treatment with serum and urinary calcium measurements. questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement among the following:

options.label: B
options.text: PTHR1 is the principal receptor for PTH and PTHrP.

options.label: C
options.text: PTHrP acts primarily via autocrine/paracrine pathways.

options.label: D
options.text: Recombinant human calcitonin is useful in hypercalcemic states.

questions.correct_answer: D. Recombinant human calcitonin is useful in hypercalcemic states.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Recombinant human calcitonin is useful in hypercalcemic states.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Intermittent PTH increases bone mass: This is true and is the basis for the use of PTH analogs (teriparatide and abaloparatide) in the treatment of osteoporosis.
  • • Option A. Intermittent PTH increases bone mass:
  • • Option B. PTHR1 is the principal receptor for PTH and PTHrP: Both hormones share the same receptor, which explains their similar physiological effects.
  • • Option B. PTHR1 is the principal receptor for PTH and PTHrP:
  • • Option C. PTHrP acts primarily via autocrine/paracrine pathways: PTHrP mainly acts locally on the cells that produce it or on nearby cells, rather than having systemic effects.
  • • Option C. PTHrP acts primarily via autocrine/paracrine pathways:
  • • Summary:
  • • Summary:
  • • PTH Structure and Physiology: 84-amino-acid peptide (first 34 amino acids being crucial for its function). Acts on bone, kidney, and indirectly on the intestine to ↑ serum calcium. Regulation: PTH release inhibited by calcium and vitamin D (and vice versa). Continuous exposure to high PTH leads to bone resorption, while intermittent administration increases bone mass. PTH acts on osteoblasts, which indirectly activate osteoclasts (via RANKL) for bone resorption. PTH assays should ideally measure only the full-length, biologically active form. PTHrP Structure and Physiology: PTHrP and PTH share structural and functional homology and bind to PTHR1 (activating mutations of PTHR1 results in Jansen’s disease – hypercalcemia, short limbed dwarfism and cystic bone lesions with undetectable PTH) It is produced in many cell types and mainly acts as a paracrine factor. PTHrP is important for bone development and other functions. PTHrP and its role in calcium homeostasis is limited to disease states (especially in humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM). Calcitonin: ↓ bone resorption and ↑ renal calcium clearance. It is of limited physiologic significance in humans. Used as a tumor marker (MTC) and treatment for hypercalcemia and Paget's disease. Calcitonin from salmon is 10–100x more potent than mammalian forms – is used therapeutically to lower serum calcium in hypercalcemic states.

PTH acts on osteoblasts, which indirectly activate osteoclasts (via RANKL) for bone resorption. PTH assays should ideally measure only the full-length, biologically active form.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is usually associated with parathyroid carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HRPT2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. MEN1: Mutations in this gene are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1), a syndrome that can include parathyroid adenomas but rarely carcinoma.
  • • Option A. MEN1:
  • • Option C. CASR: Mutations in this gene cause familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH), a benign condition unrelated to parathyroid cancer.
  • • Option C. CASR:
  • • Option D. GCM2: Mutations in this gene are associated with non-syndromic familial isolated hyperparathyroidism (FIHP), which is characterized by benign parathyroid tumors.
  • • Option D. GCM2:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HRPT2 mutations are usually associated with parathyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with CKD stage 4 presents with persistent hypercalcemia and elevated PTH levels despite treatment with vitamin D analogs. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his persistent hyperparathyroidism?

options.label: C
options.text: Monoclonal outgrowth within hyperplastic parathyroid glands

questions.correct_answer: C. Monoclonal outgrowth within hyperplastic parathyroid glands
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Monoclonal outgrowth within hyperplastic parathyroid glands

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Parathyroid carcinoma: Although possible, parathyroid carcinoma is less likely in this scenario as it is relatively rare.
  • • Option A. Parathyroid carcinoma:
  • • Option B. Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1): MEN1 is a hereditary syndrome that can cause primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT).
  • • Option B. Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1):
  • • Option D. Vitamin D resistance: Can cause SHPT, but unlikely in the given clinical context.
  • • Option D. Vitamin D resistance:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Monoclonal outgrowth within hyperplastic parathyroid glands is the most likely cause of persistent hyperparathyroidism in a CKD patient.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presents with a serum calcium of 11.2 mg/dL (normal 8.5-10.5) and a parathyroid hormone (PTH) level of 110 pg/mL (normal 15-70 pg/mL). He is otherwise asymptomatic, has normal renal function, and his dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scan is within normal limits. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Parathyroidectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Observation: While observation might be considered in elderly patients with mild PHPT, it is not appropriate for a young, asymptomatic patient with elevated S.Ca levels.
  • • Option A. Observation:
  • • Option C. Cinacalcet: Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic that can lower PTH and calcium levels. However, it is not a first-line treatment for PHPT and is generally reserved for patients who are not surgical candidates or who have persistent PHPT post-surgery.
  • • Option C. Cinacalcet:
  • • Option D. Bisphosphonates: Bisphosphonates can help to prevent bone loss but do not address the underlying cause of hyperparathyroidism, which is excessive PTH secretion.
  • • Option D. Bisphosphonates:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate management for a 43-year-old male with primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT), elevated serum calcium, and PTH levels is parathyroidectomy .
  • ➤ parathyroidectomy

questions.text: A 64-year-old female with PHPT underwent parathyroidectomy. On POD 4, she experiences persistent hypocalcemia with low PTH levels, requiring continuous IV calcium infusion to maintain S.Ca. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

options.label: C
options.text: Neck Ultrasound to look for parathyroids.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Check Mg levels.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Neck exploration under general anesthesia: This is invasive and usually done if there is persistent hyperparathyroidism.
  • • Option A. Neck exploration under general anesthesia:
  • • Option C. Neck Ultrasound to look for parathyroids: Will not be providing any useful information in a post-op patient with hypoparathyroidism.
  • • Option C. Neck Ultrasound to look for parathyroids:
  • • Option D. Add Cinacalcet: Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic that lowers PTH, which is already low in this patient. It would be inappropriate and potentially worsen hypocalcemia.
  • • Option D. Add Cinacalcet:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient who has persistent hypocalcemia and low PTH levels post-parathyroidectomy, the most appropriate next step is to check magnesium levels .
  • ➤ check magnesium levels

questions.text: A 71-year-old male with abdominal pain underwent an ultrasound (USG) that showed renal stones. His serum calcium (S.Ca) is 12.3 mg/dL (normal 8.5-10.5) and his parathyroid hormone (PTH) is 135 pg/mL (normal 15-70). What should be done next?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tc99m Sestamibi SPECT

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. 24-hour urinary calcium: While this can help assess calcium metabolism, it is not the immediate next step in diagnosing the cause of the patient's hypercalcemia.
  • • Option B. 24-hour urinary calcium:
  • • Option C. DXA spine and femur: DXA scans assess bone density and can reveal osteoporosis, a potential complication of PHPT. However, the priority is to confirm the diagnosis of PHPT and localize the parathyroid adenoma.
  • • Option C. DXA spine and femur:
  • • Option D. Bisphosphonates: Bisphosphonates are used to treat osteoporosis, a potential consequence of PHPT, but not the primary hyperparathyroidism itself. They are not indicated at this stage of diagnosis.
  • • Option D. Bisphosphonates:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a 71-year-old male with suspected primary hyperparathyroidism and renal stones, the next step is Tc99m Sestamibi SPECT to localize the parathyroid adenoma.
  • ➤ Tc99m Sestamibi SPECT

questions.text: Which of the following conditions causing hypercalcemia is least likely to respond to glucocorticoid therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Vitamin D intoxication: Glucocorticoids are a standard treatment for this condition.
  • • Option A. Vitamin D intoxication:
  • • Option B. Vitamin A intoxication: Glucocorticoids are effective in treating hypercalcemia related to vitamin A intoxication.
  • • Option B. Vitamin A intoxication:
  • • Option C. Sarcoidosis: Glucocorticoids are a first-line treatment for hypercalcemia caused by sarcoidosis.
  • • Option C. Sarcoidosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The condition causing hypercalcemia that is least likely to respond to glucocorticoid therapy is non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) .
  • ➤ non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)

questions.text: A patient with breast cancer presents with dehydration and a serum calcium of 17 mg/dL. Which of the following is not a useful therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) IV Calcitonin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. IV Fluids: Aggressive hydration with isotonic saline is essential to restore intravascular volume and promote renal calcium excretion.
  • • Option A. IV Fluids:
  • • Option B. s.c Denosumab: Denosumab, a monoclonal antibody targeting RANKL, is a potent inhibitor of osteoclast activity and bone resorption, making it effective in malignancy-associated hypercalcemia.
  • • Option B. s.c Denosumab:
  • • Option C. IV Zoledronic Acid: Zoledronic acid, a bisphosphonate, is another potent inhibitor of bone resorption and is commonly used in the management of hypercalcemia of malignancy.
  • • Option C. IV Zoledronic Acid:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with severe hypercalcemia due to malignancy, IV Calcitonin is not as useful due to its transient effect and development of tachyphylaxis.
  • ➤ IV Calcitonin

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of osteoporosis presents with fatigue, nausea, and polyuria. Labs reveal hypercalcemia, metabolic alkalosis, and elevated creatinine. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Milk-alkali syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Primary hyperparathyroidism: While it can cause hypercalcemia, it is not typically associated with metabolic alkalosis and renal impairment.
  • • Option A. Primary hyperparathyroidism:
  • • Option C. Sarcoidosis: Can cause hypercalcemia but is usually associated with granulomatous inflammation and elevated 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D levels.
  • • Option C. Sarcoidosis:
  • • Option D. Vitamin D intoxication: While it can cause hypercalcemia, it is not usually associated with metabolic alkalosis and renal impairment.
  • • Option D. Vitamin D intoxication:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely cause of hypercalcemia, metabolic alkalosis, and renal impairment in an elderly woman with osteoporosis is milk-alkali syndrome .
  • ➤ milk-alkali syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with perioral numbness and tingling one day after total thyroidectomy. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.correct_answer: B. Start Calcium and calcitriol supplements.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Start Calcium and calcitriol supplements.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Start IV Zoledronate: Zoledronic acid is a bisphosphonate used to treat hypercalcemia by inhibiting bone resorption. It would worsen hypocalcemia in this patient.
  • • Option A. Start IV Zoledronate:
  • • Option C. IV fluids and forced diuresis: This is used to treat hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia.
  • • Option C. IV fluids and forced diuresis:
  • • Option D. Administer IV sodium bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate is used to correct metabolic acidosis and has no role in treating hypocalcemia. In fact it can worsen hypokalemia by causing alkalosis.
  • • Option D. Administer IV sodium bicarbonate:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate management for hypocalcemia presenting with perioral numbness and tingling post-thyroidectomy is starting calcium and calcitriol supplements .
  • ➤ starting calcium and calcitriol supplements

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with short stature, round face, obesity, shortened fourth and fifth metacarpals, hypocalcemia, and hyperphosphatemia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1A (PHP1A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism (PPHP): Individuals with PPHP have AHO features but normal calcium, phosphate, and PTH levels. They do not exhibit hormone resistance.
  • • Option A. Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism (PPHP):
  • • Option C. Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1B (PHP1B): While PHP1B also presents with hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia, it is less likely to be associated with the full spectrum of AHO features.
  • • Option C. Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1B (PHP1B):
  • • Option D. Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 2 (PHP2): PHP2 is characterized by hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia with normal urinary cAMP response to PTH, but it does not typically present with AHO features.
  • • Option D. Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 2 (PHP2):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The child's presentation with short stature, round face, obesity, shortened fourth and fifth metacarpals, hypocalcemia, and hyperphosphatemia is characteristic of Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO), which is associated with PHP1A.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding McCune Albright Syndrome ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypofunctioning endocrinopathy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia: This is a hallmark of MAS.
  • • Option A. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia:
  • • Option B. Café-au-lait spots: These are another characteristic feature of MAS.
  • • Option B. Café-au-lait spots:
  • • Option D. Increased FGF23: Polyostotic lesions can lead to elevated FGF23 levels, contributing to phosphate wasting and hypophosphatemia.
  • • Option D. Increased FGF23:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ McCune Albright Syndrome (MAS) is characterized by hyperfunctioning endocrinopathy, not hypofunctioning. It includes polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, café-au-lait spots, and increased FGF23.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with osteoporosis and a history of peptic ulcer disease is considering treatment with oral bisphosphonates. Which of the following is most suitable for him?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Risedronate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Alendronate: Requires administration on an empty stomach with water, which could be problematic for someone with peptic ulcer disease.
  • • Option A. Alendronate:
  • • Option C. Ibandronate: Also requires administration on an empty stomach and may not be well-tolerated in patients with a history of gastrointestinal issues.
  • • Option C. Ibandronate:
  • • Option D. Zoledronic acid: This is an intravenous bisphosphonate and does not address the specific concern of oral administration in a patient with peptic ulcer disease.
  • • Option D. Zoledronic acid:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Risedronate can be taken after breakfast, which is beneficial for patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease, avoiding exacerbation of symptoms.

questions.text: A patient had a hip fracture and was started on a bone protective agent. However, after 3 years of use, the patient lost follow-up and stopped therapy. Within 3 months of stopping treatment, the patient developed a new vertebral fracture. What is the drug that was likely given initially and stopped?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Denosumab

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Zoledronate and Option B. Alendronate: These are bisphosphonates, which have a longer-lasting effect on bone remodeling than denosumab. While there can be a gradual loss of bone density after discontinuing bisphosphonates, it is not as rapid or dramatic as the rebound effect seen with denosumab.
  • • Option A. Zoledronate and Option B. Alendronate:
  • • Option D. Raloxifene: This is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) with a milder effect on bone density compared to bisphosphonates and denosumab. Its discontinuation is not typically associated with a rapid increase in fracture risk.
  • • Option D. Raloxifene:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Denosumab is associated with a rapid rebound increase in bone turnover and risk of fractures upon discontinuation, which explains the new vertebral fracture within three months of stopping the drug.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presented with a Colles' fracture. She has diabetes and suffered from an MI 2 years ago and a stroke a year ago. Which of the following drugs would be the most appropriate for her osteoporosis treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alendronate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Strontium ranelate: Not available in the US and has a potential risk of cardiovascular events, which would be a concern in this patient with a history of MI and stroke.
  • • Option A. Strontium ranelate:
  • • Option C. Romosozumab: While effective in reducing fractures, it has a higher cost and is usually reserved for patients with severe osteoporosis who have failed other treatments. Its safety profile in patients with cardiovascular disease is not yet fully established.
  • • Option C. Romosozumab:
  • • Option D. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a SERM that is primarily effective in reducing vertebral fractures and has limited data on preventing non-vertebral fractures like Colles' fractures. Additionally, it carries a risk of thromboembolic events which might be a concern in this patient (but note that Raloxifene does not increase CV risk like HRT).
  • • Option D. Raloxifene:
  • • Fracture reduction data:
  • • Fracture reduction data:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alendronate is effective for reducing the risk of fractures and is generally well-tolerated, making it the most appropriate choice for a patient with a history of cardiovascular events and a Colles' fracture.

questions.text: Match the following bone protective drugs with their recommended durations of use:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Alendronate (a): Typically used for up to 5 years (iv) .
  • • Alendronate (a):
  • • 5 years (iv)
  • • Zoledronate (b): Typically used for up to 3 years (i) .
  • • Zoledronate (b):
  • • 3 years (i)
  • • Denosumab (c): Used continuously, with long-term data supporting use for up to 10 years (ii) .
  • • Denosumab (c):
  • • 10 years (ii)
  • • Romosozumab (d): Approved for use for up to 1 year (v) .
  • • Romosozumab (d):
  • • 1 year (v)
  • • Abaloparatide (e): Approved for up to 2 years (iii) .
  • • Abaloparatide (e):
  • • 2 years (iii)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Medications approved for use :
  • ➤ Medications approved for use :
  • ➤ Alendronate (a): up to 5 years. Zoledronate (b): up to 3 years. Denosumab (c): up to 10 years. Romosozumab (d): up to 1 year. Abaloparatide (e): up to 2 years.
  • ➤ Alendronate (a): up to 5 years.
  • ➤ Zoledronate (b): up to 3 years.
  • ➤ Denosumab (c): up to 10 years.
  • ➤ Romosozumab (d): up to 1 year.
  • ➤ Abaloparatide (e): up to 2 years.

questions.text: A 52-year-old depressed woman presents with a T-score of -2.8 on DEXA scan and severe hot flashes. She has a past history of hysterectomy 6 years ago. Which of the following would be the most suitable treatment for this patient to prevent fractures?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Transdermal estrogen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Equine estrogen with medroxyprogesterone: While this combination therapy is effective for osteoporosis and hot flashes, it is not necessary for women who have had a hysterectomy as it includes progestin, which is used to protect the endometrium in women with a uterus. Addition of progestin can potentially increase the risk of breast cancer as well.
  • • Option B. Equine estrogen with medroxyprogesterone:
  • • Option C. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that can be used to prevent osteoporosis. However, it can worsen hot flashes and is not the ideal choice for this patient.
  • • Option C. Raloxifene:
  • • Option D. Teriparatide: Teriparatide is an anabolic agent that stimulates bone formation. While effective for osteoporosis, it does not address menopausal symptoms and is generally reserved for patients with severe osteoporosis who have failed other treatments.
  • • Option D. Teriparatide:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transdermal estrogen is effective for both osteoporosis and severe hot flashes, and since the patient has had a hysterectomy, she does not need progestin.
